On April 4, 2025, an association of scholars and practitioners and a nonprofit research organization filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Secretary of Education and the U.S. Department of Education. Represented by private counsel from Public Citizen Litigation Group, the plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Education (ED) and its Secretary were unlawfully dismantling the Institute of Education Sciences (IES), an agency established by the Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002 (ESRA), 20 U.S.C. §§ 9501–84, to conduct and disseminate education research and statistics.

The plaintiffs contended that beginning in February 2025, the defendants took a series of actions to terminate IES's statutorily mandated functions. These actions included mass cancellation of contracts vital for IES's research, data collection, and dissemination activities (such as the National Postsecondary Student Aid Study, High School Longitudinal Studies, and Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten), a significant reduction in force (RIF) eliminating approximately 90% of IES staff, and the termination of remote access to restricted-use data and the processing of new data access applications. The plaintiffs, who rely heavily on IES's data and research for their own work, alleged that these actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706, by being contrary to law (including ESRA, the Higher Education Opportunity Act, 20 U.S.C. §§ 1015, 1015a, and the Confidential Information Protection and Statistical Efficiency Act, 44 U.S.C. § 3582(a)), arbitrary and capricious, or an unreasonable delay of agency action. They initially also raised constitutional claims regarding separation of powers and ultra vires actions, as well as violations of the Impoundment Control Act and Anti-Deficiency Act. The plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief to vacate the defendants' actions, and orders compelling the restoration of terminated programs, staff, and data access.

Judge Trevor N. McFadden was assigned to the case, and a related case (National Academy of Education, et al. v. Department of Education, et al., Case No. 1:25-cv-01266) was consolidated for a joint preliminary injunction hearing. On April 17, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction. On June 3, 2025, Judge McFadden denied the preliminary injunction, ruling in a Memorandum Opinion (2025 WL 4218003) that the plaintiffs' APA claims constituted an impermissible "programmatic" challenge seeking "wholesale modifications to agency operations writ large," rather than discrete agency actions reviewable under the APA, citing *Lujan v. Nat’l Wildlife Fed’n*. The Court also found that the constitutional claims were merely repackaged statutory claims and thus unlikely to succeed on the merits.

Following the denial of the preliminary injunction, the plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint on June 18, 2025, and a Second Amended Complaint on July 16, 2025. These amended complaints refined their claims, focusing exclusively on specific APA challenges to the termination of individual studies, the peer review program for new grants, and restricted-use data access, as well as the unreasonable delay in disclosure risk reviews. The defendants' initial motion to dismiss was rendered moot by the filing of the Second Amended Complaint. The case continues in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.
results.46322:
On March 31, 2025, several plaintiffs initiated legal actions in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, which were subsequently consolidated under Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly. The plaintiffs comprised various nonpartisan organizations—including civil rights groups, student associations, and military family organizations—alongside several national Democratic Party-affiliated organizations and two U.S. Congressional leaders. They were represented by private counsel. The defendants included the President of the United States, the Executive Office of the President, the Election Assistance Commission (EAC) and its Commissioners and Executive Director, the U.S. Departments of Justice (DOJ), Defense (DoD), Homeland Security (DHS), State, Veterans Affairs (VA), Interior (DOI), and the Small Business Administration (SBA), as well as the Federal Voting Assistance Program (FVAP) and the respective heads of these agencies, all sued in their official capacities. A national political party, the Republican National Committee, later intervened as a defendant.

The consolidated cases challenged Executive Order 14248, "Preserving And Protecting The Integrity Of American Elections," issued by the President on March 25, 2025. The plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment and injunctive relief, alleging that specific provisions of the Executive Order constituted ultra vires presidential actions that violated the constitutional separation of powers, particularly the Elections Clause (U.S. Const. art. I, § 4, cl. 1) and Electors Clause (U.S. Const. art. II, § 1, cl. 2), and federal statutes including the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA), 52 U.S.C. § 20501 et seq., the Help America Vote Act (HAVA), 52 U.S.C. § 20901 et seq., the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2), and the Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a. Other related cases challenging the Executive Order were noted in other federal courts.

The plaintiffs moved for preliminary injunctions against five sections of the Executive Order: (1) Section 2(a), which directed the EAC to require documentary proof of U.S. citizenship on the national mail voter registration form (Federal Form); (2) Section 2(b), which directed the DHS and Department of State to open databases for state and local officials and the U.S. DOGE Service to identify "unqualified voters"; (3) Section 2(d), which directed federal voter registration agencies (e.g., DoD, VA, DOI, SBA) to "assess citizenship" before providing the Federal Form to public assistance enrollees; (4) Section 7(a), which directed the Attorney General to "enforce" federal election day statutes (2 U.S.C. § 7 and 3 U.S.C. § 1) against states that count mail-in ballots received after Election Day; and (5) Section 7(b), which directed the EAC to condition federal funding to states on their compliance with an Election Day ballot receipt deadline.

On April 24, 2025, Judge Kollar-Kotelly issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order, 2025 WL 4218003, granting in part and denying in part the motions for preliminary injunction. The Court granted preliminary injunctions against Sections 2(a) and 2(d) of the Executive Order. For these sections, the Court found that the plaintiffs demonstrated a substantial likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm, and that the balance of equities and public interest favored injunctive relief. The Court reasoned that the President lacked constitutional or statutory authority to unilaterally dictate changes to the Federal Form or to compel federal agencies to assess citizenship before distributing voter registration forms, as these powers are reserved to Congress and the States or delegated to independent, bipartisan commissions with specific procedural requirements. The injunction on Section 2(a) bars the EAC, its Commissioners, and Executive Director from implementing any part of that section, including modifying the Federal Form to require documentary proof of U.S. citizenship. The injunction on Section 2(d) bars the DoD, VA, DOI, SBA, and their leaders from implementing any part of that section, including failing to provide the Federal Form to any applicant for service or assistance based on an inability to "assess citizenship."

The Court denied preliminary injunctions against Sections 2(b), 7(a), and 7(b) of the Executive Order. For Section 2(b), the Court found that the plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits, citing uncertainty regarding the agencies' implementation plans and the potential for compliance with existing Privacy Act routine uses. For Section 7(a), the Court determined that the Attorney General's directive was a matter of prosecutorial discretion and that it was unclear what lawful enforcement actions could be taken "against States" by private parties. For Section 7(b), the Court found that the plaintiffs had not demonstrated a substantial likelihood of standing, as the alleged harm from potential state funding cuts or changes to ballot deadlines was too speculative. The Court declined to require the plaintiffs to post an injunction bond. The preliminary injunctions are temporary, pending a full trial on the merits.

This case, *Washington State Association of Head Start and Early Childhood Assistance and Education Program et al. v. Kennedy, Jr. et al.*, was filed on April 28, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington before Judge Ricardo S. Martinez.

The plaintiffs consist of four state-level Head Start Associations (representing Head Start providers in Washington, Illinois, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin) and two parent-led non-profit organizations (Family Forward Oregon and Parent Voices Oakland, representing parents and caregivers). They are represented by a coalition of private and public interest attorneys, including the American Civil Liberties Union and the Impact Fund. The defendants are the Secretary of Health and Human Services (Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.), the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the Acting Assistant Secretary of the Administration for Children and Families (Andrew Gradison), the Administration for Children and Families (ACF), and the Acting Director of the Office of Head Start (Tala Hooban), all sued in their official capacities.

The plaintiffs allege that the defendants are unlawfully dismantling the Head Start program, a federally funded initiative established by Congress in 1965 to provide comprehensive early education, health, nutrition, and social services to low-income children and families, including those with disabilities, dual language learners, and those experiencing homelessness. The factual basis for the suit stems from a series of actions taken by the defendants starting in January 2025. These include:

1.  **Executive Orders (January 20-21, 2025):** President Trump issued executive orders banning "diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility" (DEIA), "gender ideology," and services to "illegal aliens" across the federal government.
2.  **OMB Funding Freeze (January 27, 2025):** The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) temporarily froze federal funds for recipients, including Head Start providers, in an effort to implement these executive orders. Although later rescinded following court injunctions in other cases, this caused immediate closures and significant financial uncertainty for numerous Head Start agencies.
3.  **March 14 DEI Letter:** HHS issued a letter prohibiting the use of federal funding for any training, technical assistance, or program expenditures that "promote or take part in diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives," without defining "DEI."
4.  **April 16 DEIA Certification:** HHS amended its Grants Policy Statement, requiring agencies receiving new grants to certify they would not "operate any programs that advance or promote DEI, DEIA, or discriminatory equity ideology in violation of Federal anti-discrimination laws." Non-compliance could result in fund claw-backs and civil/criminal liability under the False Claims Act.
5.  **Mass Office Closures and Layoffs (April 1, 2025):** HHS abruptly closed half of its regional Head Start offices (in 23 states) and laid off approximately 60% of the Office of Head Start (OHS) staff, including crucial "Program Specialists." This severely hampered grant administration, monitoring, and support for agencies.
6.  **OMB Memorandum (April 10, 2025):** An OMB memorandum stated that the President's budget does not fund Head Start and directed HHS/ACF to prepare to "close out the program."
7.  **Delayed Funding and Designation Renewals:** Agencies experienced extreme delays in receiving annual grant approvals, accessing allocated funds through the Payment Management System (PMS), and decisions on their designation renewals, leading to payroll issues, staff layoffs, and program suspensions (e.g., one Washington-based agency closed, impacting 400 children and 70 staff).
8.  **Termination of Research Projects (May 2, 2025):** Defendants reportedly planned to terminate dozens of research projects aimed at improving Head Start operations.

The plaintiffs assert eleven causes of action, alleging that the defendants' actions violate the constitutional principles of Separation of Powers (Article I, Sections 8 & 9) and the First and Fifth Amendments (Due Process, Void for Vagueness), as well as the Administrative Procedure Act (APA, 5 U.S.C. § 706) by being contrary to law, in excess of statutory authority, arbitrary and capricious, and without observance of required procedure. They also claim violations of Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794) and that the actions are ultra vires.

The plaintiffs seek declaratory judgment that the dismantling of Head Start, the DEI Letter, and the DEIA Certification are unconstitutional and unlawful. They also request preliminary and permanent injunctive relief to vacate and set aside the defendants' actions, compel the designation and refunding of eligible Head Start agencies, enjoin the implementation of office closures, layoffs, and the DEIA Ban, order the reinstatement of federal employees, and mandate notice to all Head Start grant recipients.

As of August 5, 2025, oral arguments were held on the plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Injunction and Motion for Temporary Restraining Order. The court subsequently deemed the Motion for Temporary Restraining Order moot due to defendants' stipulation, converting it to a preliminary injunction motion, which remains pending with a hearing scheduled for September 9, 2025. The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion to file a Second Amended Complaint on August 19, 2025. Other federal courts have issued injunctions against similar administrative actions in related cases concerning other federal programs.

On May 29, 2025, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle, two Roman Catholic Bishops (of Yakima and Spokane), two Auxiliary Bishops, and six Roman Catholic priests (collectively, "the clergy") filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Tacoma. The clergy, represented by private law firms and religious liberty organizations, sued the Governor of Washington, the Attorney General of Washington, and 39 County Prosecuting Attorneys, all sued in their official capacities. The lawsuit challenges Washington State Senate Bill 5375, signed into law on May 2, 2025, and set to become effective on July 27, 2025.

The challenged law modifies Washington Revised Code § 26.44.030 to add "any member of the clergy" to the list of mandatory reporters for suspected child abuse or neglect, explicitly removing the statutory priest-penitent privilege for information learned in confession. Under Roman Catholic doctrine, priests are "absolutely forbidden" from disclosing information shared during the Sacrament of Confession, with violation resulting in automatic excommunication and risking eternal damnation. The clergy argue that SB 5375 forces them into an impossible choice between their religious obligations and facing criminal prosecution (a gross misdemeanor punishable by up to 364 days in jail and a $5,000 fine) and civil liability.

The clergy's complaint alleges violations of the First Amendment's Free Exercise and Establishment Clauses, the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution, and Article I, Section 11 of the Washington Constitution. They argue the law is not neutral or generally applicable because it targets clergy while treating comparable secular activities more favorably; for instance, a concurrently passed law, Substitute House Bill 1171, expanded privileged communication exemptions for attorneys and their staff at higher education institutions, even when related to child abuse. The clergy further contend that SB 5375 infringes on church autonomy by interfering with internal governance and ministerial supervision and commandeers religious practices for state purposes. They sought declaratory judgment that the law is unconstitutional and preliminary and permanent injunctive relief to prevent its enforcement, along with attorneys' fees and costs under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.

On June 5, 2025, the clergy filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction. On July 14, 2025, a hearing was held before U.S. District Judge David G. Estudillo. Prior to the hearing, on June 23, 2025, the United States of America, represented by the Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division, moved to intervene in the case, which Judge Estudillo granted on July 15, 2025. The United States also filed its own Motion for Preliminary Injunction on June 25, 2025, but later withdrew it on July 23, 2025, after the court ruled on the clergy's motion. Furthermore, on July 15, 2025, the clergy reached a stipulation with the 39 County Prosecuting Attorneys, agreeing to stay proceedings against them in exchange for their consent to be bound by the court's preliminary injunction and waiver of appeal and fee claims.

On July 18, 2025, Judge Estudillo granted the clergy's Motion for Preliminary Injunction, finding that they were likely to succeed on the merits of their Free Exercise Clause challenge. The court concluded that SB 5375 impermissibly burdens sincere religious practice by forcing clergy to violate the sacramental seal or face severe penalties. It found the law was neither neutral nor generally applicable, citing the disparate treatment of clergy compared to other professionals who retain privileged communication exemptions under similar circumstances (like attorneys under SHB 1171). The court also determined that the law failed strict scrutiny as it was not narrowly tailored to a compelling governmental interest. The court noted that the clergy faced irreparable harm due to the loss of First Amendment freedoms and that the balance of equities and public interest favored an injunction. While acknowledging serious questions regarding the Church Autonomy Doctrine and Establishment Clause claims, the court did not reach these issues for its ruling. The injunction prevents the Governor and Attorney General from enforcing SB 5375 as to the Sacrament of Confession against the individual clergy plaintiffs and all Roman Catholic priests in Washington who fall directly under the administration of Archbishop Etienne and Bishops Daly and Tyson, pending a final judgment on the merits.

Separately, on August 28, 2025, the court issued an order for the plaintiffs in this case to show cause why it should not be consolidated with a related case, *Orthodox Church in America et al v. Ferguson et al*, Case No. 2:25-cv-01537.
results.46678:
The State of California and its Governor filed a lawsuit on June 9, 2025, against the President of the United States, the Secretary of Defense, and the U.S. Department of Defense. Represented by the Attorney General of California, the plaintiffs alleged that the federal defendants unlawfully federalized and deployed members of the California National Guard to Los Angeles in response to protests. The federal defendants were represented by the U.S. Department of Justice.

The factual basis for the case began on June 6, 2025, when federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) conducted enforcement actions in Los Angeles. These actions led to widespread public protests, some of which involved violence and property damage. On June 7, the President issued a memorandum citing "numerous incidents of violence and disorder" and "credible threats of continued violence" as reasons to federalize 2,000 California National Guard members under 10 U.S.C. § 12406, asserting that these conditions constituted a "form of rebellion" or rendered him unable to execute federal laws with regular forces. The Secretary of Defense subsequently issued orders for federalization, followed by a second order on June 9 for an additional 2,000 National Guard members, and the deployment of 700 active-duty Marines. The Governor of California objected to these actions, contending that local law enforcement was capable of managing the situation, that the federalization was unlawful and unconstitutional, and that it bypassed his authority as Commander-in-Chief of the state's National Guard while exacerbating public tensions.

The plaintiffs' complaint, filed with Judge Charles R. Breyer in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, asserted three causes of action: ultra vires (that the federal defendants exceeded their statutory and constitutional authority), violation of the Tenth Amendment (infringement on state sovereignty and police powers), and violation of the Administrative Procedure Act against the Department of Defense defendants. They also argued that the deployment violated the Posse Comitatus Act (18 U.S.C. § 1385) by involving the military in domestic law enforcement. The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment that the federalization orders were invalid and injunctive relief to prohibit the deployment of the federalized National Guard and military forces for domestic law enforcement, demanding the return of control of the California National Guard to the Governor. They also requested costs and attorneys' fees.

On June 10, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an Ex Parte Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO). After a hearing and considering the defendants' opposition, Judge Breyer granted the TRO on June 12, 2025. The district court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims that the President's actions exceeded his statutory authority under 10 U.S.C. § 12406 (finding no "rebellion" or inability to execute laws with regular forces, and a failure to issue orders "through the governor") and violated the Tenth Amendment. The court temporarily enjoined the federal defendants from deploying the federalized California National Guard in Los Angeles and directed them to return control of the National Guard to the Governor. This order was stayed until noon on June 13, 2025. The district court's order is reported as 2025 WL 4218003.

The federal defendants immediately appealed the TRO to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals and filed an emergency motion for a stay pending appeal. On June 19, 2025, the Ninth Circuit granted the federal defendants' motion for a stay of the TRO. The appellate court found that the federal defendants made a strong showing of likely success on the merits of their appeal, concluding that under a highly deferential standard of review, the President likely acted within his authority under 10 U.S.C. § 12406(3) (inability to execute laws with regular forces) and that the procedural requirement of issuing orders "through the governor" was likely met by transmittal to the Adjutant General. The Ninth Circuit's order is reported as *Newsom v. Trump*, No. 25-3727 (9th Cir. June 19, 2025).

Following the TRO and appeal, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction on June 16, 2025. A bench trial on the preliminary injunction was held before Judge Charles R. Breyer from August 11 to August 13, 2025. The outcome of this trial is not specified in the provided documents.
results.46287:
On March 25, 2025, the American Association of University Professors (AAUP) and the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), both labor unions representing faculty and academic professionals, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. The unions, represented by private counsel, sued the United States Department of Justice (DOJ), the U.S. Attorney General, a Senior Counsel to the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights and head of the DOJ Task Force to Combat Anti-Semitism, the United States Department of Education (DOE), the U.S. Secretary of Education, the Acting General Counsel of the DOE, the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the U.S. Secretary of HHS, the Acting General Counsel of HHS, the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Acting Director of NIH, the United States General Services Administration (GSA), the Acting Administrator of GSA, and the Commissioner of the Federal Acquisition Service.

The lawsuit stemmed from actions taken by these federal agencies against non-party Columbia University. Following an Executive Order by President Trump on January 29, 2025, directing agencies to combat antisemitism on campuses, the agencies initiated investigations into Columbia for alleged failures to address antisemitism. On March 7, 2025, the federal agencies summarily canceled approximately $400 million in federal grants and contracts to Columbia, citing the university's "continued inaction" and stating that the funding "no longer effectuate[d]... agency priorities" or was "for the convenience of the Government." Three days later, the NIH confirmed terminating over $250 million, comprising more than 400 grants, for nonalignment with agency priorities for safe research environments. On March 13, 2025, the federal agencies sent a letter to Columbia outlining nine "preconditions" for "formal negotiations" regarding the university's "continued financial relationship with the United States government," which was valued at over $5 billion. These demands included enforcing disciplinary policies with "expulsion or multi-year suspension" for protesters, abolishing the University Judicial Board, banning masks, placing the Middle East, South Asian, and African Studies (MESAAS) department under academic receivership, and reforming admissions practices. Columbia subsequently announced its own reforms on March 21, 2025, many of which aligned with, but did not entirely match, the government's demands.

The labor unions alleged that these federal actions violated their members' First Amendment rights to free speech and academic freedom (including under the unconstitutional conditions doctrine), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) due to procedural and substantive failures, the constitutional separation of powers (as ultra vires executive actions), the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause, and the Tenth Amendment and Spending Clause. They argued that the agencies failed to follow the specific procedural requirements of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act for terminating federal funding and that the actions were arbitrary and capricious. The unions sought a declaratory judgment, a preliminary and permanent injunction to reinstate the terminated funding to Columbia, halt further interference with funding without proper process, and prevent enforcement of the demands, as well as compensatory and nominal monetary damages for their members.

The case was assigned to Judge Mary Kay Vyskocil. On April 3, 2025, the labor unions filed a motion for a preliminary injunction. The federal agencies opposed, arguing that the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the unions and their members lacked Article III and prudential standing, and because the claims were contractual in nature, falling under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Court of Federal Claims via the Tucker Act (citing *Dep’t of Educ. v. California*, 145 S. Ct. 966 (2025)). They also argued that the decision to withdraw funding was committed to agency discretion and thus unreviewable under the APA. On the merits, the federal agencies contended their actions complied with the APA, did not violate the First Amendment (as they targeted conduct, not speech), and were permissible exercises of Executive Branch authority based on agency priorities.

On June 16, 2025, Judge Vyskocil issued an Opinion & Order denying the labor unions' motion for a preliminary injunction and dismissing the case without prejudice for lack of standing. The Court found that neither the unions nor their members were the direct recipients of the terminated grants and contracts, which belonged to non-party Columbia University. The Court noted that Columbia itself was engaged in negotiations and administrative appeals regarding the funding. It concluded that the unions failed to demonstrate a cognizable injury to themselves or to their members that was fairly traceable to the defendants, citing that Columbia's own actions and planned reforms predated the federal demands and that members' alleged "chilling effect" was subjective and speculative. The Court also noted that the agencies terminated funding based on "agency priorities" and "convenience," not explicitly under Title VI, which does not directly address religious discrimination.

The labor unions filed a Notice of Appeal from the Opinion and Order on June 16, 2025.

On May 7, 2025, sixteen states and the District of Columbia, represented by their respective Attorneys General, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), its Secretary Sean Duffy, the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA), and its Acting Administrator Gloria M. Shepherd. The plaintiffs, who are individual sovereign states and the District of Columbia, were later joined by seven environmental and public interest organizations (Sierra Club, Natural Resources Defense Council, Climate Solutions, Southern Alliance for Clean Energy, CleanAIRE NC, West End Revitalization Association, and Plug In America), represented by public interest law firms and in-house counsel, whose motion to intervene as party plaintiffs was granted on July 23, 2025.

The lawsuit arose after President Trump issued Executive Order No. 14,154, "Unleashing American Energy," on January 20, 2025, directing federal agencies to immediately pause the disbursement of funds appropriated through the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), specifically targeting the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program. Following this, on January 29, 2025, Secretary Duffy issued DOT Order No. 2100.7, establishing new policy priorities for DOT grantmaking, some of which were unrelated to transportation and included social criteria. On February 6, 2025, the FHWA issued a letter rescinding its existing NEVI Formula Program Guidance and retroactively suspending all previously approved State Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Deployment Plans. This action effectively froze approximately $2.74 billion in congressionally appropriated NEVI funds, preventing states from obligating funds for electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure projects.

The IIJA, enacted in 2021, had appropriated $5 billion for the NEVI Formula Program to strategically deploy EV charging infrastructure nationwide, with funds to be distributed to states and the District of Columbia using a mandatory, non-discretionary formula and to remain available until expended. States had developed detailed plans, which the FHWA had approved, and had begun implementing projects, awarding contracts, and committing state resources in reliance on these federal funds. The defendants' actions halted these efforts, causing immediate harms such as project delays and cancellations, loss of private sector partners, increased administrative burdens, and impediments to achieving state-level EV adoption and emissions reduction goals.

The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by exceeding statutory authority, being arbitrary and capricious, and failing to observe procedures required by law. They also claimed violations of the U.S. Constitution's Separation of Powers Doctrine (Article I, Section 1) and the Take Care Clause (Article II, Section 3), and asserted a common law ultra vires claim, arguing the Executive Branch impermissibly usurped congressional spending power.

Presiding over the case, Judge Tana Lin heard arguments on the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. On June 24, 2025, Judge Lin issued an order (2025 WL 4218003) granting in part and denying in part the motion. The preliminary injunction was granted for fourteen states (Arizona, California, Colorado, Delaware, Hawaiʻi, Illinois, Maryland, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Washington, and Wisconsin), enjoining the defendants from suspending or revoking their previously approved State Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Deployment Plans and from withholding or withdrawing NEVI Formula Program funds without adhering to the IIJA's requirements. The court ordered that these states' plans be restored to their legal status prior to February 6, 2025. The injunction was denied for the District of Columbia, Minnesota, and Vermont due to insufficient evidence of irreparable harm beyond the complaint's allegations. The injunction was initially stayed for seven days to allow for a potential appeal, but this stay was lifted on July 2, 2025, as no appeal was filed. The preliminary injunction remains in effect pending further orders from the court. The parties subsequently filed motions for summary judgment on August 26, 2025.

On March 13, 2025, eight students from Columbia University and Barnard College, suing under pseudonyms, filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against Columbia University, its Trustees and Interim President, the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Education and the Workforce (the "Committee") and its Chairman. The students, represented by private attorneys and non-profit legal organizations like CAIR, alleged that the Committee was unlawfully coercing the University to suppress protected speech and association related to pro-Palestinian activism. An amended complaint on March 19, 2025, added federal officials from the Departments of Justice, Education, Health and Human Services, and the General Services Administration—collectively forming a "Task Force to Combat Anti-Semitism"—as defendants, alleging their involvement in the coercive campaign.

The factual basis of the case centers on alleged "jawboning" tactics by the federal entities. The Committee, since early 2024, has demanded student disciplinary records from the University, culminating in a February 13, 2025, letter. The Task Force, established by a presidential executive order, threatened to withhold "billions in federal funding" from Columbia, with $400 million in grants already canceled by March 7, 2025, citing the University’s failure to address antisemitism. Plaintiffs allege these actions are intended to punish and suppress pro-Palestinian viewpoints on campus. They claim that the University, under this pressure, has implemented policies such as harsher disciplinary procedures, a mask ban, expanded campus law enforcement with arrest powers, and placed the Middle East, South Asian, and African Studies (MESAAS) department under "academic receivership," while also adopting an expansive definition of antisemitism for disciplinary purposes. Prior disclosures of student information to the Committee in an October 31, 2024, report allegedly led to doxing, harassment, and even the detention of one plaintiff by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The students, who have engaged in pro-Palestinian activism, fear further irreparable harm to their reputations, careers, and personal safety.

The students brought claims under the First Amendment (freedom of speech and association), the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act, along with a breach of contract claim against the University. They seek a declaratory judgment, permanent injunctions to prevent Congress from compelling student records, to enjoin federal agencies from coercing the University by withholding funds to suppress speech, and to prevent the University from complying with these demands. They also seek monetary damages for records already produced.

Judge Arun Subramanian is presiding over the case. On March 18, 2025, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion to proceed under pseudonyms and provisionally sealed certain exhibits. The students initially sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction to halt further disclosures and funding cuts. On March 20, 2025, the Court temporarily enjoined the University from providing records or identifying student information to Congress pending a hearing. However, on April 4, 2025, the Court denied the TRO/PI motion without prejudice, vacating the temporary injunction. The Court noted that the initial complaint and motion papers failed to address standing and irreparable harm from the funding threats and Columbia's policy changes. The Court also found that the Speech or Debate Clause likely barred relief directly against the Congressional defendants for their legislative acts. To allow for renewed motions, the Court granted the students leave to file a second amended complaint by April 18, 2025, and ordered the University to provide 30 days' notice before any future disclosures of student records or identities to Congress. The Court subsequently denied the plaintiffs' request to extend this notice requirement to Columbia’s narrative response to a separate request from the Senate HELP Committee.

On April 18, 2025, the students filed their Second Amended Complaint. All defendant groups (Congressional, University, and Federal Agency) filed motions to dismiss the Second Amended Complaint on May 23, 2025. Amicus curiae briefs were filed by Palestine Legal (May 23, 2025) and Defending Rights & Dissent (July 2, 2025) in support of the plaintiffs. On June 18, 2025, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the federal agency defendants in their individual capacities only, retaining them in their official capacities. Following the denial of the initial TRO/PI, the plaintiffs filed a renewed motion for a preliminary injunction on June 20, 2025, alongside their opposition briefs to the motions to dismiss. A Stipulation and Protective Order was entered on May 14, 2025, to govern the handling of the pseudonymous plaintiffs' personally identifiable information. Briefing on the motions to dismiss and the renewed preliminary injunction motion is ongoing.
results.46557:
On May 5, 2025, nineteen states and the District of Columbia, represented by their respective Attorneys General, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island against Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., in his official capacity as Secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), along with HHS itself and several of its sub-agency leaders and sub-agencies (including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Administration for Children and Families (ACF), Administration for Community Living (ACL), and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)).

The plaintiffs alleged that HHS Secretary Kennedy issued a directive on March 27, 2025 (the "March 27 Directive") to dismantle the Department. This directive called for the termination of 10,000 HHS employees, the reorganization of 28 sub-agencies into 15 (including the creation of three new agencies like the "Administration for a Healthy America"), and the closure of half of HHS's ten regional offices. This action followed earlier layoffs of probationary employees and was explicitly acknowledged by Secretary Kennedy as a rapid, "decisive action" taken to maintain "political momentum," despite foreseeing that up to 20% of the terminations would be "mistakes" due to a lack of careful, line-by-line review of job responsibilities.

The plaintiffs contended that these actions immediately and severely disrupted critical, statutorily mandated public health and human services. Specific allegations included the shuttering of CDC infectious disease laboratories (affecting testing for rare diseases, STIs, and viral hepatitis), the elimination of CDC's Division of Reproductive Health (halting data collection for maternal and infant health programs like PRAMS and support for Maternal Mortality Review Committees), the near-total demolition of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), the incapacitation of the FDA's Center for Tobacco Products (CTP) and CDC's Office on Smoking and Health (OSH) (halting compliance checks, premarket reviews, and public education campaigns), significant staff reductions in the Office of Head Start within ACF (disrupting grant administration and technical assistance for early childhood education programs), and the termination of the entire team responsible for annually updating the federal poverty guidelines within the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation (ASPE). These disruptions, plaintiffs argued, left states without essential federal resources, expertise, and data, forcing them to divert their own strained resources or risk significant negative public health and welfare outcomes for their residents.

The lawsuit asserted five causes of action: violations of the U.S. Constitution's Separation of Powers Doctrine (Article I, Section 1 and Article II, Section 3) and Appropriations Clause (Article I, Section 9, Clause 7), ultra vires conduct by federal officials, and violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (5 U.S.C. § 706) as the actions were "contrary to law" and "arbitrary and capricious." The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including a preliminary and permanent injunction to prevent the directive's implementation, and vacatur of the directive.

On May 9, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction. After expedited briefing and a hearing on May 20, 2025, District Judge Melissa R. DuBose granted the preliminary injunction on July 1, 2025. The Court ruled that the plaintiff states had standing and that their claims were not barred by the Civil Service Reform Act or the Tucker Act. The Court found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their APA claims, concluding that HHS's actions were both "arbitrary and capricious" due to a lack of reasoned explanation and failure to consider crucial impacts, and "contrary to law" because they made it functionally impossible for HHS to comply with numerous congressional mandates and effectively disregarded appropriated funds. The Court declined to address the constitutional claims at that stage. The Court also found that the plaintiffs faced irreparable harm and that the balance of equities and public interest weighed heavily in their favor. A nominal bond of $100 was imposed.

On July 18, 2025, Judge DuBose denied the defendants' motion to vacate the preliminary injunction or, in the alternative, for a stay pending appeal, stating that recent Supreme Court summary orders in other cases would not short-circuit the appellate process for this case given its distinct basis. On August 12, 2025, the Court issued a revised preliminary injunction order, clarifying that HHS and all named defendants were enjoined from implementing the planned reductions in force (RIFs) or sub-agency restructuring announced in the March 27 Directive with respect to: the CTP; OHS and its regional office staff; CDC's National Center for HIV, Viral Hepatitis, STD, and Tuberculosis Prevention (NCHHSTP), Division of Reproductive Health (DRH), NIOSH, OSH, National Center for Environmental Health (NCEH), and National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities (NCBDDD); and ASPE's Division of Data and Technical Analysis. The injunction prevents further RIFs, issuance of new RIF notices, and placement of additional employees on administrative leave, "until further order of this Court."

The defendants filed a Notice of Appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit on August 12, 2025 (USCA Case Number 25-1780).
results.46511:
This case was filed on April 29, 2025, by 24 states and the District of Columbia (referred to as "the states") against the Corporation for National and Community Service, operating as AmeriCorps, and its Interim Head, Jennifer Bastress Tahmasebi (collectively, "the federal agency"). The states were represented by their respective Attorneys General or Governors' offices, while the federal agency was represented by attorneys from the U.S. Department of Justice.

The underlying dispute arose from the Trump Administration's efforts, initiated in January 2025 through the "Department of Government Efficiency" (DOGE), to dismantle federal programs and personnel without Congressional approval. Regarding AmeriCorps, these actions included: on April 15, 2025, placing over 750 members of the National Civilian Community Corps (NCCC) on administrative leave pending termination; on April 16, 2025, placing 85% of the federal agency’s paid staff on administrative leave (followed by reductions in force); and on April 25, 2025, abruptly terminating over 1,000 AmeriCorps grants, totaling nearly $400 million (approximately 41% of AmeriCorps’ budget), and ordering the immediate cessation of all volunteer activities for roughly 30,000 AmeriCorps and VISTA (Volunteers in Service to America) members. The federal agency justified these terminations by stating the awards "no longer effectuate agency priorities," without providing prior notice or opportunity for comment. The states alleged that these actions caused immediate and irreparable harm to essential state-administered service programs in areas like disaster relief, education, public health, environmental stewardship, and veteran support, which rely heavily on AmeriCorps funding and volunteers.

The states sought declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the federal agency's actions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by being contrary to law, arbitrary and capricious, and undertaken without required public notice and comment rulemaking. They also claimed violations of the U.S. Constitution's Separation of Powers doctrine, arguing that the Executive Branch unlawfully usurped Congress's power of the purse and failed to faithfully execute laws, and that the actions were ultra vires.

On May 6, 2025, the states filed a motion for a preliminary injunction. An amicus brief in support of the states' motion was filed by thirty-three bipartisan former governors on May 12, 2025. On June 5, 2025, U.S. District Judge Deborah L. Boardman issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order, granting in part the states' motion for a preliminary injunction. The Court found that the states were likely to succeed on their APA claim that the federal agency failed to engage in notice-and-comment rulemaking, as required by the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2024, Pub. L. 118-47, § 401, 138 Stat. 460, 695 (and incorporated by reference for Fiscal Year 2025), before making "significant changes to program requirements, service delivery or policy."

The June 5, 2025 Order (2025 WL 4218003) enjoined the federal agency from enforcing the April 25, 2025 grant terminations and member removals in the plaintiff states, and from enforcing the April 15, 2025 removal of NCCC members nationwide. It ordered the federal agency to restore the affected AmeriCorps programs, reinstate terminated grants, and return AmeriCorps and VISTA members to service (if willing and able). The order also required the federal agency to comply with the notice-and-comment rulemaking requirement before making any future significant changes in service delivery. The Court denied the request to enjoin the reduction in AmeriCorps staff, citing a lack of standing. A nominal bond of $100 per plaintiff was imposed.

Following a Supreme Court decision in *Trump v. CASA, Inc.*, 606 U.S. ----, 2025 WL 1773631 (June 27, 2025), which limited the scope of universal injunctions, the federal agency moved to modify the injunction. With the states' consent, Judge Boardman issued a Modified Preliminary Injunction on July 10, 2025. This modified order clarified that the requirement for notice-and-comment rulemaking applies only to significant changes in service delivery that *harm the plaintiff states*, rather than universally. The preliminary injunction remains in effect until further order of the Court.
results.46350:
On April 7, 2025, the American Library Association (ALA), a non-profit membership organization, and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO (AFSCME), a national labor organization, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. They sued Keith Sonderling, the Acting Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS), IMLS itself, President Donald Trump, and other federal officials and agencies, including the U.S. DOGE Service and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel from Democracy Forward Foundation and Gair Gallo Eberhard LLP.

The lawsuit stemmed from President Trump's Executive Order No. 14,238, issued on March 14, 2025, which declared IMLS "unnecessary" and directed it to reduce its statutory functions and personnel to the minimum required by law. Following this, on March 20, 2025, Keith Sonderling, who allegedly lacked the statutory qualifications, was appointed Acting Director of IMLS and announced his intent to align the agency with the administration's agenda of "patriotism." By March 31, 2025, IMLS, with assistance from the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), placed all 75 IMLS employees on indefinite administrative leave, cut off their access to agency systems, and threatened to terminate all grants. On April 3, 2025, termination notices were sent to most IMLS staff, leaving only 12 employees. On April 4, 2025, Acting Director Sonderling fired all 23 members of the National Museum and Library Services Board. By April 9, 2025, IMLS began canceling grants to state libraries and, specifically, terminated two grants held by ALA. These actions led to immediate harms, such as the Maine State Library announcing layoffs and a temporary closure due to lost IMLS funding.

The plaintiffs alleged violations of the U.S. Constitution's Article I (Separation of Powers, Spending Clause, Appropriations Clause), Article II, Section 3 (Take Care Clause), and the First Amendment, asserting that the defendants' actions constituted an unlawful unilateral dismantling of a congressionally mandated agency and an unconstitutional condition on federal funding. They also claimed violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 706(1) and 706(2)(A)-(C), arguing the actions were arbitrary, capricious, in excess of statutory authority, and unlawfully withheld agency action. Additionally, they brought claims under the Impoundment Control Act and the Paperwork Reduction Act, and an equitable claim of ultra vires conduct. The plaintiffs sought declaratory judgments, a preliminary and permanent injunction to halt the dissolution of IMLS, reinstate employees and grants, restore agency operations, and recover costs and attorney's fees.

Presiding over the case, Judge Richard J. Leon of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, initially converted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction into a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) on April 30, 2025. On May 1, 2025, the Court issued a Memorandum Order granting in part the TRO, preserving the status quo as of that date, and later extended it to May 29, 2025. During these proceedings, the defendants argued the Court lacked subject-matter jurisdiction, citing related appellate decisions such as *Department of Education v. California*, 2025 WL 1008354 (Apr. 4, 2025), and *Widakuswara v. Lake*, 2025 WL 1288817 (D.C. Cir. May 3, 2025), which addressed similar challenges to federal grant terminations and personnel actions, often channeling such claims to the Court of Federal Claims or administrative bodies under the Civil Service Reform Act.

On May 6, 2025, the defendants filed a motion for reconsideration of the TRO, citing the D.C. Circuit's reasoning in *Widakuswara*. On June 6, 2025, Judge Leon issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order, denying the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction without prejudice and denying the defendants' motion for reconsideration as moot. The Court also denied as moot the plaintiffs' subsequent motion for a temporary restraining order. The judge noted that the plaintiffs "may not be able to show that this Court has jurisdiction" over claims related to grant terminations (which typically fall under the Tucker Act for the Court of Federal Claims) and personnel actions (governed by the Civil Service Reform Act), thus failing to meet the high bar for preliminary injunctive relief. The order directed the parties to file a joint status report proposing next steps, leading to a schedule for dispositive motions, including the defendants' anticipated motion to dismiss.
results.46746:
On June 27, 2025, two environmental non-profit organizations, Friends of the Everglades, Inc. and Center for Biological Diversity, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida. The lawsuit named as defendants the Secretary of the United States Department of Homeland Security, the Acting Director of United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (federal officials), the Executive Director of the Florida Division of Emergency Management (a state official), and Miami-Dade County. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel from Earthjustice, Center for Biological Diversity, and Coffey Burlington, P.L., alleged violations of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), 42 U.S.C. § 4321 et seq., the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 701 et seq., and applicable provisions of Florida law and Miami-Dade County Code. They sought declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to halt the unlawful construction and operation of a mass federal detention facility, referred to as "Alligator Alcatraz," at the Dade-Collier Training and Transition Airport (TNT Site).

The factual basis of the case is the rapid construction of a detention facility for up to 5,000 noncitizen detainees at the TNT Site, which is owned by Miami-Dade County and located within or adjacent to the ecologically sensitive Big Cypress National Preserve and Big Cypress Area in South Florida. This area is critical habitat for endangered and threatened species such as the Florida panther and Florida bonneted bat. The plaintiffs asserted that the state and federal officials proceeded with the construction and operation of the facility without conducting required environmental reviews, public notice or comment, or compliance with other federal statutes and state or local land-use laws. They also sought a declaration that the state official's actions were ultra vires and that the county's acquiescence violated local codes. The state official, represented by the Office of the Attorney General of Florida and Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, maintained that the facility was constructed using state funds under emergency powers to assist federal immigration enforcement. Federal officials, represented by the U.S. Department of Justice, acknowledged that the facility operates under 287(g) agreements for federal immigration purposes and that federal funding for a Detention Support Grant Program, for which the state agency is the only eligible applicant, was announced.

The case was assigned to Judge Kathleen M. Williams. On June 27, 2025, the environmental organizations filed an Expedited Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) and Preliminary Injunction. On July 14, 2025, the Miccosukee Tribe of Indians of Florida, represented by private counsel, successfully moved to intervene as a plaintiff, citing its long-standing ties to the affected lands and the environmental risks to its food and water supply. The court held a four-day Preliminary Injunction Hearing on August 6, 7, 12, and 13, 2025. During the proceedings, the court granted the environmental organizations' motion for expedited discovery on July 28, 2025.

On August 7, 2025, Judge Williams issued an Order granting in part the environmental organizations' Renewed Motion for TRO. This order prohibited the state and federal officials from installing additional industrial-style lighting, paving, filling, excavating, fencing, or any other site expansion, including new buildings or residential/administrative facilities at the TNT site for 14 days.

On August 21, 2025, Judge Williams issued an Omnibus Order (2025 WL 1482733) granting in part and denying in part the environmental organizations' Motion for Preliminary Injunction. The Preliminary Injunction prohibits the state and federal officials from (1) installing any additional industrial-style lighting (described as "Sunbelt" lighting), paving, filling, excavating, or fencing, or any other site expansion (including additional buildings, tents, dormitories, or other residential or administrative facilities) on the TNT site; and (2) bringing any additional persons onto the TNT site who were not already being detained at the time the order went into effect. The injunction allows for modifications or repairs to existing facilities solely for the purpose of increasing safety or mitigating environmental or other risks. Furthermore, the order mandates that, no later than 60 days from the date of the order, and once the population attrition allows for safe implementation, the defendants shall remove temporary fencing, Sunbelt lighting fixtures and any additional lighting installed for the detention facility, and all generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and waste receptacles that were installed to support the project. The existing housing and detention dormitory facilities may remain and be maintained to prevent deterioration or damage. The plaintiffs were required to post a bond of $100.

Both the state official and the federal officials subsequently filed Notices of Interlocutory Appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit (Case No. 25-12873) on August 21 and August 23, 2025, respectively. They also filed motions to stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal, which the District Court denied on August 27, 2025. Other related cases referenced in the proceedings include C.M. v. Noem, 25-cv-23182 (S.D. Fla.) (2025 WL 2400953) and Garcia v. Guthrie, No. 25-cv-23136 (S.D. Fla.).
results.46388:
This case was initially filed on April 11, 2025, by two faculty associations, the American Association of University Professors—Harvard Faculty Chapter and the American Association of University Professors, along with a labor union representing academic workers, the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America. These plaintiffs are represented by private law firms. The lawsuit names numerous federal agencies and their respective high-ranking officials in their official capacities as defendants.

The plaintiffs allege violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the First Amendment's Free Speech Clause, the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause, and the Separation of Powers/Spending Clause (Article I) of the U.S. Constitution. The APA claims are largely based on the alleged failure to follow procedures outlined in Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000d et seq.). The plaintiffs seek a declaratory judgment, preliminary and permanent injunctive relief to set aside the defendants' actions and enjoin future similar actions, along with attorneys' fees and costs. The case is presided over by Judge Allison D. Burroughs.

The factual basis of the case centers on the Trump administration's alleged campaign to control American universities by leveraging federal funding. This campaign began with Executive Orders in January 2025, targeting "DEI programs" and antisemitism, leading to the formation of a multi-agency "Task Force to Combat Anti-Semitism." Similar federal actions, including funding freezes, were reportedly taken against other universities like Columbia, Cornell, and Northwestern.

Regarding Harvard University, the defendants, comprising various federal agencies (including the Departments of Justice, Education, Health and Human Services, General Services Administration, Energy, Defense, Agriculture, Housing and Urban Development, and the National Science Foundation, and National Aeronautics and Space Administration), announced on March 31, 2025, a "comprehensive review" of Harvard's federal funding, citing unspecified failures to address antisemitism and "promoting divisive ideologies." On April 3, the defendants sent a letter to Harvard, alleging it "fundamentally failed" to protect students and demanding "immediate" and sweeping "reforms" as preconditions for continued funding. These demands included programmatic changes to "improve viewpoint diversity and end ideological capture," overhauling student discipline, enacting a "mask ban," and "shuttering" all "DEI programs." An April 11 letter expanded on these demands, adding requirements such as a "comprehensive audit" of hiring and admissions for "viewpoint diversity," reporting foreign students for conduct violations, and sanctioning faculty.

On April 14, Harvard rejected these demands, asserting violations of its First Amendment and statutory rights. Hours later, the defendants announced a freeze of over $2 billion in federal funding to Harvard. Subsequently, on May 5, the Secretary of Education declared that Harvard would receive no future federal grants due to its alleged "systemic pattern of violating federal law" and its refusal to implement the administration's "common-sense reforms." Between May 6 and May 12, various federal agencies issued letters terminating approximately $2.7 billion in grants to Harvard, citing general allegations of antisemitism and race discrimination and Harvard's non-compliance with the earlier demands. The defendants also cited 2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4) (agency priorities) as a basis for some terminations.

The plaintiffs contend that these actions have caused severe and irreparable harm to their members—faculty, graduate students, and researchers—by halting academic research, delaying experiments, jeopardizing careers, forcing layoffs, and disrupting academic progress. This includes research in critical areas such as public health, national defense, and scientific advancement. The plaintiffs also assert that the defendants' actions have created a pervasive climate of fear and self-censorship on campus, leading some members to modify their research and teaching. They highlight that Harvard has already made some concessions, such as centralizing student discipline and closing its DEI office, demonstrating the coercive impact of the defendants' actions. The plaintiffs argue that the defendants failed to follow Title VI's mandatory procedural requirements (such as notice, hearing, and specific findings) and that their actions were arbitrary, capricious, unconstitutional coercion, viewpoint discrimination, and retaliation.

In the course of proceedings, the court granted motions to seal certain affidavits and for leave to file excess pages. Plaintiffs' initial emergency motion for a temporary restraining order was withdrawn. Plaintiffs were granted leave to file a Second Amended Complaint on May 20, 2025. Both Plaintiffs and Defendants filed motions for summary judgment, with oral arguments scheduled for July 21, 2025. The case is associated with other related matters, including *President and Fellows of Harvard College v. U.S. Department of Health and Human Services et al.* (1:25-cv-11048-ADB) and *President & Fellows of Harvard College v. U.S. Department of Homeland Security* (1:25-cv-11472).
results.46625:
On May 21, 2025, a group of non-profit organizations, including the Vera Institute of Justice, Center for Children & Youth Justice, Chinese for Affirmative Action (d/b/a Stop AAPI Hate), FORCE Detroit, and Health Resources in Action, filed a class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The plaintiffs, represented by private and non-profit legal organizations, sued the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), U.S. Attorney General Pamela J. Bondi, the Office of Justice Programs (OJP), and Maureen A. Henneberg (Acting Head of OJP), all in their official capacities.

The lawsuit challenged OJP's abrupt, "en masse" termination in April 2025 of over 370 multi-year cooperative agreements and grants, totaling more than $820 million, without prior notice. OJP informed grantees via identical form emails that their awards "no longer effectuate[] the program goals or agency priorities" due to a change in DOJ priorities to focus on supporting law enforcement operations, combating violent crime, protecting children, and assisting victims of trafficking and sexual assault. The plaintiff organizations, however, asserted that their terminated grants directly supported these very purposes, covering initiatives such as violence reduction, victims' services (including sign language interpretation for Deaf victims), juvenile justice, anti-AAPI hate crime support, and hospital-based violence intervention programs. The terminations allegedly caused immediate and irreparable harm, including cessation of vital community services, staff layoffs, and reputational damage.

The plaintiffs brought claims under the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause (alleging deprivation of property interest without notice and void for vagueness), an equitable ultra vires claim, and claims alleging violations of the constitutional separation of powers, the Spending and Appropriations Clauses, and the Take Care Clause. They also alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), specifically that OJP's actions were contrary to law (2 C.F.R. § 200.340(a)(4)) and arbitrary and capricious (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A)). They sought declaratory judgments, preliminary and permanent injunctive relief to reinstate funding and prevent future similar terminations, and an order directing fund disbursement, along with costs and attorney fees.

The case was assigned to Judge Amit P. Mehta. Plaintiffs filed motions for preliminary injunction and class certification, while defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing lack of subject matter jurisdiction (under the Tucker Act, citing *Department of Education v. California*, 145 S. Ct. 966 (2025)), and failure to state claims on the merits. Amicus curiae briefs were filed by various state attorneys general and community-based public safety subgrantees in support of the plaintiffs.

In a Memorandum Opinion issued on July 7, 2025 (2025 WL 4218003), Judge Mehta acknowledged that OJP's terminations were "unquestionably arbitrary, at least in lay terms," "shameful," and "unfair and indiscriminate," noting that defendants' counsel could not explain the specific reasons for the terminations. However, the court denied the preliminary injunction and granted the motion to dismiss, finding that it lacked jurisdiction over the plaintiffs' APA claims, deeming them "essentially contractual in nature" and thus belonging in the Court of Federal Claims. The court also dismissed the constitutional and ultra vires claims for failure to state a plausible claim. The motion for class certification was denied as moot.

Following this, plaintiffs filed a Notice of Appeal to the D.C. Circuit Court (USCA Case #25-5248) and an Emergency Motion for Injunction Pending Appeal in the district court. On July 21, 2025, Judge Mehta issued an Order (2025 WL 4403063) granting in part the emergency motion. While denying a broad affirmative injunction, the court issued a narrower injunction, prohibiting the defendants from re-obligating or otherwise diminishing the specific grant funds that were awarded to the five named plaintiffs. This limited injunction is set to remain in effect until October 1, 2025, without a bond requirement.
results.46274:
On March 8, 2025, a nonprofit financial institution, Climate United Fund, initiated a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against Citibank, N.A., the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin. Subsequently, additional nonprofit financial institutions (Coalition for Green Capital, Power Forward Communities, Inc., Justice Climate Fund) and state green banks (California Infrastructure and Economic Development Bank, Efficiency Maine Trust, Illinois Finance Authority, Minnesota Climate Innovation Finance Authority) filed similar individual lawsuits, which were later consolidated into this action before Judge Tanya S. Chutkan. The plaintiffs are represented by private counsel and state attorneys general, while the federal defendants are represented by attorneys from the U.S. Department of Justice, and Citibank by private counsel.

The plaintiffs alleged that Congress, through the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 (42 U.S.C. § 7434), established the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) and appropriated $27 billion for competitive grants to invest in clean energy. In April 2024, the EPA awarded billions in grants to the plaintiffs, with funds held at Citibank under Financial Agency Agreements (FAA) with the U.S. Treasury Department and Account Control Agreements (ACA) with EPA and each grantee. These agreements specified conditions for the EPA to exercise exclusive control over the funds.

Beginning in mid-February 2025, following the new EPA Administrator's public statements expressing hostility towards the GGRF program, Citibank allegedly ceased disbursing funds to the plaintiffs, citing directives from the EPA and Treasury. The plaintiffs contended that the EPA, through various actions including FBI "recommendations" and Treasury directives, unlawfully orchestrated this freeze without legal justification or due process. On March 11, 2025, the EPA issued "Notices of Termination" to the primary grantees, citing concerns about program integrity, misalignment with agency priorities, and alleged deficiencies in oversight and account controls, effective immediately.

The plaintiffs asserted claims for breach of contract, replevin, and conversion against Citibank. Against the EPA and Administrator Zeldin, they alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (5 U.S.C. § 706(2)), the Appropriations Clause of the U.S. Constitution (Article I, Section 9, Clause 7), and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. They sought declaratory judgments that Citibank breached the ACAs, that the EPA's actions violated federal law, and that the termination was null and void. They also sought injunctive relief to compel Citibank to disburse funds, enjoin the EPA from impeding Citibank, and prevent the EPA from unlawfully suspending or terminating the grants.

On March 18, 2025, the court issued a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) (2025 WL 842360), which was extended multiple times, enjoining the EPA from giving effect to the termination letters or implementing the termination (including transferring, re-obligating, or re-allocating funds, or issuing a Notice of Exclusive Control). The TRO also enjoined Citibank from transferring funds to any party other than the accountholders but did not compel Citibank to disburse funds. The court also denied a motion to intervene by Tarek Farag.

On April 15, 2025, the court granted the plaintiffs' consolidated motion for a preliminary injunction. This order enjoined the EPA defendants from effectuating the March 11, 2025, Notices of Termination, from unlawfully suspending or terminating grants (including by issuing a Notice of Exclusive Control or limiting access to funds except as permitted by the ACAs, grant awards, and applicable law), and from directly or indirectly impeding Citibank. The order also enjoined Citibank from transferring funds except as permitted and, significantly, ordered Citibank to disburse funds properly incurred before the mid-February suspension. The court waived the bond requirement under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65(c) and denied the federal defendants' contingent emergency motion for a stay pending appeal without prejudice. This preliminary injunction remains in effect pending further orders from the District Court. On April 16, 2025, both the federal defendants (USCA Case #25-5122) and Citibank (USCA Case #25-5123) filed notices of appeal to the D.C. Circuit Court.
results.46110:
On February 12, 2025, five federal employee unions—the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU), National Federation of Federal Employees (NFFE), International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM), International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE), and the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW)—filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The unions, represented by private counsel, brought the action as individual plaintiffs against the President of the United States and various federal agency heads (including the Acting Director of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the Acting Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), and the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), among others). The defendants were represented by the U.S. Department of Justice.

The lawsuit challenged three executive actions initiated by the Trump Administration, alleging these actions collectively aimed to dismantle the federal government workforce. First, OPM directed federal agencies to identify and determine whether to retain probationary employees, leading to mass firings of an estimated 220,000 such employees across various agencies, including the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) and the Department of Veterans Affairs. Second, OPM implemented a "deferred resignation program" in January 2025, inviting federal employees to resign by September 30, 2025, while retaining pay and benefits; approximately 75,000 employees opted into this program before it closed on February 12, 2025. Third, on February 11, 2025, the President issued Executive Order No. 14210, titled "Implementing the President’s ‘Department of Government Efficiency’ Workforce Optimization Initiative," which directed agencies to prepare for large-scale reductions-in-force (RIFs), prioritizing employees in non-mandated functions, diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives, and those deemed nonessential during government shutdowns (an estimated 345,000 employees). Firings under this Executive Order also began in February 2025.

The unions asserted two causes of action: first, that the mass firings and forced resignations violated separation of powers principles by undermining Congress's authority to create, fund, and assign missions to federal agencies (based on the U.S. Constitution, Article I, Section 1); and second, that agency defendants were violating the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by implementing RIFs contrary to statutory and regulatory requirements (citing 5 U.S.C. § 3502 and 5 C.F.R. Part 351). The unions sought declaratory judgment that these actions were unlawful, injunctive relief to halt the implementation of Section 3(c) of Executive Order No. 14210, OPM's directive to terminate probationary employees, any extension of the deferred resignation program, and all violations of RIF statutes and regulations, plus attorneys' fees and costs.

The case was initially assigned to Judge Paul L. Friedman and then randomly reassigned to Judge Christopher R. Cooper. On February 14, 2025, the unions filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction. On February 20, 2025, Judge Cooper denied this motion, ruling that the court likely lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the claims fell within the exclusive administrative and judicial review scheme established by Congress in the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS).

Following this ruling, the unions filed an Amended Complaint on February 17, 2025, and a Second Amended Complaint on June 6, 2025, which updated the factual basis to reflect ongoing terminations and added new defendants. On May 15, 2025, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the Amended Complaint. However, on May 27, 2025, the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW) voluntarily dismissed itself as a plaintiff. Subsequently, on June 6, 2025, Judge Cooper granted the unions' motion to amend their complaint, striking the defendants' May 15th motion to dismiss, and ordered the defendants to respond to the Second Amended Complaint by June 27, 2025. The defendants filed a new motion to dismiss the Second Amended Complaint on July 11, 2025. As of the last available docket entry, this motion is pending.
results.46098:
On February 11, 2025, a group of nonprofit organizations and businesses, including the Global Health Council, Small Business Association for International Companies, HIAS, Management Sciences for Health, Inc., Chemonics International, Inc., DAI Global, LLC, Democracy International, Inc., and the American Bar Association, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. These plaintiffs, represented by private law firms and public interest groups, sued President Donald J. Trump (in his official capacity), the Secretary of State, the Acting Director of Foreign Assistance, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), and the U.S. Department of State, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), and OMB. The case was consolidated with *AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition v. U.S. Department of State*, Civil Action No. 25-cv-00400, and assigned to Judge Amir H. Ali.

The plaintiffs challenged Executive Order 14,169, issued on January 20, 2025, which announced a "pause" on all U.S. foreign assistance funding, claiming it was "antithetical to American values" and not aligned with the President's foreign policy. This Executive Order led to directives from the State Department, USAID, and OMB, halting funding, issuing stop-work orders, recalling thousands of USAID employees, and initiating mass terminations of foreign assistance awards. The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Impoundment Control Act of 1974 (2 U.S.C. §§ 682 et seq.), the Anti-Deficiency Act Amendments of 1982 (31 U.S.C. §§ 1301(a), 1512(c)(1)), the 2024 Appropriations Act (Pub. L. No. 118-47), the constitutional separation of powers (U.S. Const. art. I, §§ 8 & 9, and art. II, § 3), ultra vires actions, and procedural due process (Fifth Amendment). They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including vacatur of the challenged directives and orders, and mandamus relief, to compel the defendants to release and obligate appropriated funds.

On February 13, 2025, the District Court issued a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), granting in part the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary relief. The TRO enjoined the defendants (excluding the President) from enforcing certain sections of the Secretary of State's January 24, 2025, memorandum and other directives implementing Executive Order 14,169 by suspending, pausing, or preventing the obligation or disbursement of appropriated foreign assistance funds for awards existing as of January 19, 2025, or by issuing, implementing, or enforcing terminations, suspensions, or stop-work orders for such awards.
