The court explicitly allowed actions to enforce the terms of particular contracts. Following multiple motions to enforce the TRO due to alleged non-compliance, the District Court reiterated its order, including requiring the disbursement of funds for work completed prior to February 13, 2025.

On March 10, 2025, the District Court issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction (2025 WL 752378). The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA claims that the initial directives implementing a blanket suspension of foreign aid (between January 20 and February 13, 2025) were arbitrary and capricious, particularly due to the failure to consider substantial reliance interests. However, the court found the plaintiffs were unlikely to succeed on APA claims challenging subsequent large-scale terminations of awards that occurred after the TRO, deeming these distinct agency actions not adequately challenged in the current litigation. The court also found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their constitutional claims that the defendants' wholesale withholding of congressionally appropriated foreign aid funds violated the separation of powers, as the Executive lacked unilateral authority to impound funds for policy reasons without following statutory procedures. The injunction (60) enjoined defendants from giving effect to terminations, suspensions, or stop-work orders issued between January 20 and February 13, 2025, and from withholding payments for work completed prior to February 13, 2025. It also enjoined defendants from unlawfully impounding congressionally appropriated foreign aid funds and ordered them to make available for obligation the full amount of funds appropriated in the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2024. The court set a benchmark for payment processing and required weekly status reports on compliance.

The defendants appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit (Case #25-5097). On August 13, 2025, the D.C. Circuit issued an opinion (2025 WL 2129854) vacating the part of the District Court's preliminary injunction involving impoundment. The Circuit Court concluded that the plaintiffs lacked a cause of action to bring their freestanding constitutional claim or an APA claim to enforce the Impoundment Control Act, finding that the ICA's detailed scheme for interbranch dialogue and enforcement by the Comptroller General implicitly precluded private enforcement. The D.C. Circuit reasoned that the plaintiffs' claims, although framed as constitutional, were fundamentally statutory violations that could not be transformed into a constitutional cause of action. The court remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with its opinion.
results.PC-VA-0022:
The case of Eric J. DePaola v. Virginia Department of Corrections, et al., Case No. 7:14CV00692, was filed on December 19, 2014, in the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia. Initially filed by multiple plaintiffs seeking class action certification, the motion for class certification was denied, and the case proceeded with Eric J. DePaola as an individual, pro se plaintiff. The defendants included the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC), its Director, its Chief of Operations, various VDOC officials, and numerous supervisory and treatment officials at Red Onion State Prison (ROSP).

The inmate, Eric J. DePaola, was sentenced in 2004 to 38 years for malicious wounding, use of a firearm, statutory burglary, and abduction. After being transferred to Red Onion State Prison (ROSP) in 2007, he was placed in administrative segregation (solitary confinement) in 2009 following a stabbing incident involving a prison guard. The inmate challenged VDOC Operating Procedure 830.A (OP 830.A), the "Segregation Reduction Step-Down Program," alleging violations of his Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses and the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. He sought monetary damages and injunctive relief to abolish OP 830.A and alleviate harsh conditions at ROSP.

The inmate contended that OP 830.A discriminated against "Intensive Management" (IM) inmates, who, unlike "Special Management" (SM) inmates, were permanently barred from progressing out of solitary confinement regardless of their behavior. He alleged his assignment to IM status was arbitrary and lacked due process, with reviews being meaningless and susceptible to false reporting by officers. He also complained of severe and unconstitutional conditions in solitary confinement, including small, unsanitary cells, constant bright lights, and inadequate meals, which he claimed caused mental illness, anxiety, sleep loss, physical deterioration, and vision problems.

The case was presided over by Judge James P. Jones. Key filings included motions to certify class, to appoint counsel, to dismiss, for a protective order, to amend the complaint, and for summary judgment. The motions to certify class and appoint counsel were denied. The motion for a protective order was granted. The motion to amend the complaint was granted, and the motion to dismiss was denied. The VDOC was dismissed as a defendant due to being an improper party under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.

The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on September 27, 2016, finding that the inmate's confinement conditions, while restrictive, did not constitute an "atypical and significant hardship" because he could theoretically progress within the IM privilege levels. The court concluded there was no Fourteenth Amendment procedural due process or Equal Protection violation, and no Eighth Amendment violation. The district court's opinion is cited as DePaola v. Va. Dep’t of Corrs., No. 7:14-cv-00692 (W.D. Va. Sept. 28, 2016), ECF No. 76. The judgment was subsequently affirmed by an unpublished per curiam opinion in the Fourth Circuit on November 22, 2017.
results.46387:
On April 11, 2025, the law firm Susman Godfrey LLP, represented by private counsel, filed a complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief against the Executive Office of the President, the United States of America, numerous federal agencies (including the U.S. Department of Justice, Office of Management and Budget, Securities and Exchange Commission, and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission), and their respective officials in their official capacities. The case was assigned to Judge Loren L. AliKhan.

The lawsuit challenged Executive Order 14,263, titled "Addressing Risks from Susman Godfrey," which President Donald J. Trump issued on April 9, 2025. This Executive Order was part of a series of similar orders targeting other law firms, some of which resulted in settlements where firms agreed to provide pro bono services to Administration-approved causes to avoid sanctions.

The Executive Order accused Susman Godfrey of "spearhead[ing] efforts to weaponize the American legal system and degrade the quality of American elections"—a reference to the firm's representation of Dominion Voting Systems and state election officials in litigation concerning the 2020 presidential election. It also alleged the firm "fund[ed] groups that engage in dangerous efforts to undermine the effectiveness of the United States military" (in reference to a donation to GLBTQ Legal Advocates and Defenders) and "engage[d] in unlawful discrimination, including . . . on the basis of race" (referring to the Susman Godfrey Prize and general diversity initiatives).

The Executive Order mandated several punitive actions:
*   Section 2 directed federal agencies to immediately suspend active security clearances held by Susman employees and review them, and to cease providing government goods, property, and services benefiting the firm.
*   Section 3 required government contractors to disclose any business with Susman and directed agencies to terminate contracts where Susman was hired for services.
*   Section 4 referenced a prior Executive Order, signaling investigations into law firms' diversity, equity, and inclusion policies.
*   Section 5 directed agencies to limit Susman employees' access to federal buildings and engagement with federal employees, and to refrain from hiring Susman employees without a specific waiver.

Susman Godfrey alleged that the Executive Order violated the First Amendment (retaliation for protected expression, viewpoint discrimination, infringement on the right to petition, free association, and unconstitutional conditions on government contracts). It also claimed violations of the Fifth Amendment (procedural due process, void for vagueness, right to counsel, and equal protection), and the Constitution's separation of powers (ultra vires presidential action). The firm sought a declaratory judgment that the Executive Order was unconstitutional and injunctive relief to halt its implementation.

On April 14, 2025, Susman Godfrey filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO). Judge AliKhan granted the TRO on April 15, 2025 (2025 WL 1113408), enjoining Sections 1, 3, and 5 of the Executive Order, and extended it on April 16, 2025, pending final judgment.

Following cross-motions for summary judgment and to dismiss, on June 27, 2025, Judge AliKhan denied the federal government's motion to dismiss and granted Susman Godfrey's motion for summary judgment. The court ruled that Executive Order 14,263 was unconstitutional, null, and void, based on violations of the First and Fifth Amendments (specifically Counts I, II, III, IV, VI, VII, VIII, and IX of the Amended Complaint). A permanent injunction was issued, prohibiting the federal government, its agencies, and officials from implementing, enforcing, or relying on any part of the Executive Order, and directing them to rescind all related guidance, reverse any suspensions or revocations, and operate as if the order had never been issued. The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the order.

On August 22, 2025, the federal government filed a notice of appeal to the D.C. Circuit Court (USCA Case Number 25-5310).
results.46245:
On March 18, 2025, the United States Institute of Peace (USIP), an independent nonprofit corporation established by Congress, along with five of its presidentially-appointed Board members, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The plaintiffs, initially represented by private counsel from Picard Kentz & Rowe LLP and Zuckerman Spaeder LLP, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against Kenneth Jackson (purported acting president of USIP), the U.S. DOGE Service (a newly created entity within the Executive Office of the President), its Temporary Organization, several DOGE employees, and various high-ranking federal officials including the U.S. Secretaries of State and Defense, the President of the National Defense University (who also serve as ex officio USIP Board members), and the President of the United States.

The factual basis for the case originated on February 19, 2025, when the President issued Executive Order 14217, declaring USIP "unnecessary" and directing the reduction of its statutory functions and personnel to a minimum. Following this, on March 14, 2025, the White House Presidential Personnel Office e-mailed USIP's appointed Board members, including the plaintiffs, informing them of their immediate termination, without adhering to the specific removal procedures outlined in the United States Institute of Peace Act, 22 U.S.C. § 4605(f). The remaining three ex officio Board members then purportedly removed USIP President Ambassador George Moose and appointed Kenneth Jackson as acting president. On March 17, 2025, representatives from DOGE, backed by FBI agents and D.C. Metropolitan Police, forcibly took over USIP's headquarters building, which USIP owned and had administrative jurisdiction over. Subsequently, the new purported USIP leadership terminated nearly all of USIP's over 400 employees, replaced Kenneth Jackson with Nate Cavanaugh as acting president, and initiated the transfer of USIP's headquarters building (valued at $500 million and largely funded by private donations) and its $25 million Endowment to the General Services Administration (GSA).

The plaintiffs, including additional Board member Nancy Zirkin and Ambassador George Moose in individual and official capacities in an amended complaint, alleged that the President's actions violated the separation of powers doctrine, were *ultra vires*, and specifically violated the USIP Act (22 U.S.C. §§ 4605, 4606). They also claimed trespass to real and personal property. They sought declaratory judgments stating that the purported removals and appointments were unlawful, null, and void, and injunctive relief prohibiting further trespass, restoring the lawful Board and President, and enjoining defendants from exercising unauthorized control over USIP's resources. The case, presided over by Judge Beryl A. Howell, involved a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO), which was denied on March 19, 2025, and a motion under the All Writs Act to suspend property transfer, which was denied on April 1, 2025.

On May 19, 2025, Judge Howell granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment (2025 WL 1428641). The court ruled that USIP, while a governmental entity for constitutional purposes, does not exercise executive power and is not part of the Executive Branch. Therefore, the President's removal of the appointed Board members violated the USIP Act's removal protections (22 U.S.C. § 4605(f)), which were held to be constitutional. The court declared the purported removal of the appointed Board members and Ambassador Moose, and the subsequent appointments of Kenneth Jackson and Nate Cavanaugh as presidents, as unlawful, null, and void. All actions taken by Jackson or Cavanaugh as purported presidents, including the transfer of USIP's headquarters and financial assets to GSA, were also declared invalid. The court issued a permanent injunction, ordering the plaintiff Board members and Ambassador Moose to continue serving in their respective roles and enjoining defendants (except ex officio Board members to the extent of their lawful positions) from further trespass, and from maintaining unauthorized access or control over USIP's property and resources.

The defendants appealed this decision to the D.C. Circuit (Case #25-5185) and filed an emergency motion for a stay pending appeal and an administrative stay. On June 27, 2025, a motions panel of the D.C. Circuit granted the defendants' motion for a stay pending appeal, finding that the government was likely to succeed on the merits because USIP exercises "substantial executive power," which would make the Board's removal protections unconstitutional under Article II, citing *Seila Law LLC v. CFPB*, 140 S. Ct. 2183 (2020), and *Trump v. Wilcox*, 145 S. Ct. 1415 (2025) (a related case concerning other agencies). The panel also found irreparable harm to the President's executive powers and that a stay was in the public interest. On June 29, 2025, the plaintiffs-appellees filed a petition for rehearing en banc and an emergency administrative stay of the June 27 order. The D.C. Circuit denied the motion for en banc reconsideration on July 24, 2025. Related cases involving similar challenges to presidential removals are pending in the D.C. Circuit.
results.46142:
On February 19, 2025, the National Urban League (NUL), the National Fair Housing Alliance, and the AIDS Foundation of Chicago (AFC) filed a civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The lawsuit was assigned to Judge Timothy J. Kelly following a transfer from Judge Loren L. AliKhan. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and non-profit legal organizations including the NAACP Legal Defense & Educational Fund, Inc. and Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, Inc., are non-profit organizations that rely heavily on federal grants and contracts to pursue their missions of advancing diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility (DEIA), and promoting the rights of people of color, women, and LGBTQ+ individuals. The National Fair Housing Alliance later voluntarily dismissed its claims on June 27, 2025.

The plaintiffs sued the President of the United States and numerous federal departments and agencies, along with their respective heads or acting directors, in their official capacities. These defendants included the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs (OFCCP), U.S. Departments of Labor (DOL), Health and Human Services (HHS), Commerce (DOC), Housing and Urban Development (HUD), Agriculture (USDA), National Institutes of Health (NIH), Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Administration for Community Living (ACL), U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ).

The lawsuit challenges three Executive Orders issued by President Donald J. Trump on January 20-21, 2025: Executive Order No. 14151 ("Ending Radical and Wasteful DEI Programs and Preferencing"), Executive Order No. 14168 ("Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government"), and Executive Order No. 14173 ("Ending Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit-Based Opportunity"). These orders aim to eliminate DEIA programs and what the Administration terms "gender ideology" from the federal government and private entities receiving federal funds. The orders direct agencies, among other things, to terminate "equity-related" grants and contracts, end federal funding of "gender ideology," and require contractors and grantees to certify that they do not operate DEI programs violating federal anti-discrimination laws, with compliance deemed material under the False Claims Act. The orders also contemplate identifying and investigating private entities involved in such programs.

Plaintiffs allege that these Executive Orders and related agency actions violate their First Amendment rights (viewpoint and content discrimination, chilling of speech) and Fifth Amendment rights (Due Process Clause, including void-for-vagueness, and Equal Protection Clause, alleging discrimination based on race, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, and transgender status). They also claim the orders constitute ultra vires presidential action, exceeding the President's authority by usurping Congress's power over federal spending (Article I, Sections 7 and 9) and contravening existing federal statutes designed to support equity and address discrimination.

As remedies, plaintiffs seek a declaratory judgment that the Executive Orders and their implementing actions are unlawful, unconstitutional, and invalid. They also request a permanent injunction to prevent defendants from enforcing these orders against them, including mandates to rescind agency directives, rectify affected contracts and grants, and provide notice to affected parties, along with an award of costs and attorney's fees.

Plaintiffs cited several related cases involving similar challenges to these or previous administration policies, including *National Council of Nonprofits v. OMB* (2025 WL 314433, 2025 WL 368852, 2025 WL 597959), *New York v. Trump* (2025 WL 357368), *Santa Cruz Lesbian and Gay Community Ctr. v. Trump* (508 F. Supp. 3d 521), *Nat’l Ass’n of Diversity Officers in Higher Educ. v. Trump* (2025 WL 573764, stayed by 4th Cir. on Mar. 14, 2025), *Chi. Women in Trades v. Trump* (2025 WL 933871, 2025 WL 1114466), *San Francisco AIDS Foundation v. Trump* (2025 WL 1621636), and *Thakur v. Trump* (2025 WL 1734471).

On February 28, 2025, plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction. On March 5, 2025, a non-profit organization named "Do No Harm" filed a motion to intervene as a defendant, which the Court denied without prejudice on March 12, 2025, allowing it to participate as amicus curiae. On May 2, 2025, Judge Kelly denied the plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Injunction, finding that they were not likely to succeed on the merits of their facial constitutional challenges, and for some claims, had failed to establish standing. This ruling was reported as *National Urban League et al. v. Trump et al.*, 2025 WL 1978727 (D.D.C. May 2, 2025).

Following the preliminary injunction denial and the voluntary dismissal of one plaintiff, NUL and AFC filed a First Amended and Supplemental Complaint on June 30, 2025, removing the Administrative Procedure Act as a separate cause of action and updating factual allegations to include specific harms, such as the termination of a $500,000 EPA grant for NUL's Urban Environmental Justice Collaborative Program and directives from HRSA to AFC to censor language related to gender and DEIA in its program materials.
results.46090:
On February 9, 2025, the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) filed a complaint, later amended on February 13, 2025, with multiple individual and organizational plaintiffs including the National Consumer Law Center, National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), Virginia Poverty Law Center, Pastor Eva Steege (later substituted by her husband, Ted Steege, for her estate), and the CFPB Employee Association. These plaintiffs, represented by private law firms and union counsel, sued Russell Vought in his official capacity as Acting Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) and the CFPB itself.

The lawsuit alleged that the Executive Branch was unlawfully attempting to dismantle the CFPB, an independent agency created by Congress in 2010 through the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act to protect consumers and ensure financial stability. This effort, plaintiffs claimed, violated constitutional separation of powers principles, the Appointments Clause of the U.S. Constitution (challenging Vought's appointment under the Federal Vacancies Reform Act), and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by exceeding statutory authority and acting arbitrarily and capriciously (5 U.S.C. §§ 706(2)(A), (C)). Plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief (including temporary restraining orders and preliminary injunctions), and attorneys' fees.

The factual basis for the suit began on January 31, 2025, when President Trump fired CFPB Director Rohit Chopra. Interim Acting Director Scott Bessent and subsequently, on February 7, 2025, Acting Director Russell Vought (also Director of the Office of Management and Budget) issued directives pausing most CFPB activities, with Vought explicitly ordering a "stop work" to all employees on February 10, 2025, unless approved by the Chief Legal Officer. President Trump publicly stated his goal to "totally eliminate" the CFPB. The agency's website was taken offline, and Elon Musk (head of the "Department of Government Efficiency," DOGE, whose personnel were embedded at CFPB) posted "CFPB RIP." These actions were followed by the termination of approximately 85 probationary and 130 term employees (including the statutorily mandated Private Education Loan Ombudsman), the cancellation of over $100 million in contracts, and plans for a large-scale Reduction in Force (RIF) affecting nearly all remaining CFPB employees.

On February 14, 2025, U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson converted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order into a motion for a preliminary injunction. The court entered a consent order (Doc 19) temporarily prohibiting data destruction, most employee terminations, RIF notices, and fund transfers. After evidentiary hearings on March 10-11, 2025, Judge Jackson issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order on March 28, 2025 (Doc 87, 88), granting the preliminary injunction. The court found a likelihood of success on the merits, concluding that defendants were engaged in an unlawful, concerted effort to dismantle the CFPB in violation of separation of powers principles and the APA. The injunction ordered the defendants to maintain agency data, reinstate previously terminated probationary and term employees, cease further RIFs or terminations (except for cause), not enforce the stop-work order, provide employees with necessary work access, ensure the Office of Consumer Response maintained its complaint systems, and rescind contract termination notices.

Defendants appealed this preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit (Case No. 25-5091) on March 29, 2025. Related cases included *NTEU v. Trump*, 2025 WL 561080 (D.D.C. Feb. 20, 2025), where Judge Cooper denied a preliminary injunction for NTEU's employment claims, and *Mayor and City Council of Baltimore v. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau*, 2025 WL 814500 (D. Md. Mar. 14, 2025). On April 11, 2025, the D.C. Circuit issued a partial stay of the District Court's injunction (Doc 2110720), allowing RIFs and work stoppages *only if* defendants conducted a "particularized assessment" that affected employees/work were unnecessary to statutory duties. Following this, on April 17, 2025, the CFPB issued RIF notices to 1408 employees. On April 18, 2025, Judge Jackson issued an interim order (Doc 113) suspending this RIF and prohibiting the cutoff of employee computer access, pending a hearing to determine compliance with the partially stayed injunction. Defendants appealed this interim order (Case No. 25-5132). On April 28, 2025, the D.C. Circuit lifted its partial stay of the RIF prohibition (Doc 2113309), fully reinstating the District Court's ban on RIFs. Appeal No. 25-5132 was voluntarily dismissed by defendants on May 7, 2025, and granted on May 12, 2025.

Ultimately, on August 15, 2025, the D.C. Circuit (Judges Katsas and Rao, with Judge Pillard dissenting) vacated the District Court's preliminary injunction (Doc 2130273, 2025 WL 2130273). The majority held that the District Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the employment-related claims of the NTEU and CFPB Employee Association, as these claims must proceed through the exclusive review scheme of the Civil Service Reform Act. For the remaining plaintiffs, the D.C. Circuit concluded that their claims targeted neither "final agency action" reviewable under the APA (as the alleged "shutdown decision" was abstract and not a sufficiently discrete, binding agency statement) nor unconstitutional action reviewable in equity (as the claims were statutory violations rephrased as constitutional ones, per *Dalton v. Specter*). The case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with the appellate court's opinion.
results.PB-CT-0007:
On November 9, 2010, six same-sex couples and one widower, all legally married in Connecticut, Vermont, or New Hampshire, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut. These individual plaintiffs, represented by private attorneys and public interest legal organizations, sued federal agencies and officials, including the Office of Personnel Management, the Secretaries of the Treasury and Labor, the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, the United States Postal Service, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and the United States of America. The plaintiffs alleged that Section 3 of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), 1 U.S.C. § 7, violated the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause.

The plaintiffs contended that DOMA Section 3, which defined "marriage" and "spouse" for all federal purposes as exclusively between one man and one woman, discriminatorily denied them federal protections, benefits, and responsibilities available to similarly situated opposite-sex married couples. Specific harms included a retired federal employee's spouse being denied "Self and Family" health insurance coverage under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHB); a widower being denied a "One-Time Lump-Sum Death Benefit" from the Social Security Administration and a Qualified Preretirement Survivor Annuity (QPSA) under his deceased spouse's private pension plan; a federal employee being denied leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) to care for her ill spouse and unable to enroll her spouse in her FEHB "Self and Family" plan; retired state employees being denied a medical cost spousal benefit from the New Hampshire Retirement System due to federal tax regulations tied to DOMA; and two same-sex married couples being compelled to file federal income tax returns as "Head of Household" or "Single," resulting in higher tax burdens and denied refunds. The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment that DOMA Section 3 is unconstitutional as applied to them, an injunction to prevent its enforcement, and monetary damages for the tax-related harms ($1,465 for Suzanne and Geraldine Artis, and $2,085 for Bradley Kleinerman and James Gehre).

After the U.S. Attorney General announced in February 2011 that the Executive Branch would no longer defend DOMA Section 3, the Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group (BLAG) of the U.S. House of Representatives intervened to defend the statute. Both BLAG and the federal defendants filed motions to dismiss the complaint, while the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment. Judge Vanessa L. Bryant denied BLAG's motion to stay proceedings on July 4, 2012.

On July 31, 2012, Judge Bryant issued a Memorandum of Decision (2012 WL 3113883), denying the motions to dismiss and granting the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment. The court found that classifications based on sexual orientation are entitled to a heightened form of judicial scrutiny, but concluded that DOMA Section 3 failed even the lowest level of rational basis review. The court rejected all asserted justifications for DOMA, including defending traditional marriage, promoting responsible procreation, preserving government resources, protecting state sovereignty, and ensuring consistency, finding them to lack a rational relationship to the statute's discriminatory classification. The judgment, entered on August 2, 2012, declared DOMA Section 3 unconstitutional as applied to the plaintiffs, permanently enjoined the defendants from enforcing its discriminatory provisions, and awarded the specified monetary damages and costs.

Both the federal defendants and BLAG filed separate notices of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on August 17, 2012, and September 26, 2012, respectively. These appeals were subsequently consolidated in the Second Circuit. Additionally, both the plaintiffs and the federal defendants filed petitions for a writ of certiorari before judgment to the U.S. Supreme Court. This case is related to other ongoing challenges to DOMA, including *Windsor v. United States* and *Gill v. Office of Personnel Management*.
results.DR-CA-0033:
On August 22, 2005, a wheelchair-bound individual filed a civil complaint against Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., alleging that two of its California restaurant locations (in San Diego and Encinitas) denied him full and equal access due to architectural barriers. The plaintiff, represented by private counsel, specifically claimed that high walls (44-46 inches) in front of the food preparation counters obstructed his view of food items and their preparation, thereby preventing him from fully participating in the "Chipotle experience" of selecting and customizing his order. He also alleged inaccessible parking, entrances, restrooms, and dining tables. The lawsuit asserted causes of action under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.) and various California statutes, including the Unruh Civil Rights Act and the Disabled Persons Act. The plaintiff sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief (to mandate barrier removal and policy modification), monetary damages, and attorneys' fees.

The case was assigned to District Judge Napoleon A. Jones, Jr. In January 2006, Chipotle filed a cross-claim for indemnity and defense against the property landlords, Carl Karcher Enterprises, Inc. and El Camino Plaza Associates, which was later dismissed with prejudice. A related putative class action, *Maurizio Antoninetti, et al. v. Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc.* (Case No. 06CV2671-LAB (POR)), was filed and consolidated with this case for discovery purposes only.

In January 2007, Judge Jones denied Chipotle's motion to dismiss this case but affirmed the discovery-only consolidation. In June 2007, Judge Jones issued a partial summary judgment ruling: he granted Chipotle's motions regarding ADA claims for parking, entrances, and restrooms (finding them moot due to remediation or lacking evidence/damages sought), but granted the plaintiff's motions on state law parking claims (due to prior violations). Crucially, he denied both parties' motions for summary judgment on the food preparation counters, finding a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Chipotle's accommodation policies constituted "equivalent facilitation" under ADA Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) § 7.2(2)(iii), and ruling that the ADA's general anti-discrimination provisions did not apply. Both parties' subsequent motions for reconsideration were denied in August 2007.

A bench trial was held before Judge Jones from November 27 to December 3, 2007. On January 10, 2008, Judge Jones issued his Findings of Fact, Conclusions of Law, and Judgment: he found that Chipotle's *prior unwritten* accommodation policy *did not* constitute "equivalent facilitation," but its *current formal written* accommodation policy *did* comply with ADAAG § 7.2(2)(iii). He denied injunctive relief for the counter walls, citing the plaintiff's lack of irreparable injury and sincere intent to return to the restaurants. The plaintiff was awarded $5,000 in statutory damages under the California Disabled Persons Act for five "bona fide" visits made while the unwritten policy was in effect, but no damages for "litigation-related" visits or for multiple barriers on a single visit.

The plaintiff appealed the judgment and the subsequent attorney fees order, and Chipotle cross-appealed. On July 26, 2010, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals (643 F.3d 1165) issued an opinion that significantly altered the case: it affirmed the finding that the unwritten policy violated the ADA, but *reversed* the finding that Chipotle's *written* policy complied with the ADA. The Ninth Circuit also *reversed* the denial of injunctive relief, remanding for appropriate relief, and *vacated* the $5,000 damages award and the attorney fees award, remanding for reconsideration in light of its new rulings.

Following remand, and after the plaintiff Maurizio Antoninetti's death, his wife, Livia Antoninetti, was substituted as plaintiff. On March 21, 2012, District Judge Barry Ted Moskowitz denied injunctive relief as moot due to the plaintiff's death. He subsequently awarded $5,000 in statutory damages for the five "bona fide" visits, but again denied damages for the three "litigation-related" visits. On July 17, 2012, after reconsideration, Judge Moskowitz awarded the plaintiff $545,079.05 in attorneys' fees and costs, for a total amended judgment of $550,079.05 (including the $5,000 in damages). On December 26, 2012, the Appellate Commissioner for the Ninth Circuit awarded attorneys' fees and expenses in the amount of $353,469.95 for the appellate proceedings.
results.CJ-FL-0009:
This consolidated class action, initially filed on June 28, 2019, challenged Florida's legal framework for restoring voting rights to citizens with past felony convictions. The individual plaintiffs were felons who had completed all terms of their sentences, including incarceration and parole or probation, but still owed court-ordered financial obligations (Legal Financial Obligations or "LFOs") such as fines, fees, costs, and restitution. Many of these plaintiffs asserted they were genuinely unable to pay these LFOs, and some had already registered and voted. Organizational plaintiffs, including the Florida State Conference of the NAACP, the Orange County Branch of the NAACP, and the League of Women Voters of Florida, joined the suit, alleging that the new laws hampered their voter registration efforts and diverted resources. The defendants included the Governor of Florida, the Secretary of State of Florida, and the Supervisors of Elections for several Florida counties.

The case centered on Florida's Amendment 4, a voter-initiated constitutional amendment approved in November 2018, which restored voting rights to most felons "upon completion of all terms of sentence including parole or probation," effective January 8, 2019. In June 2019, the Florida Legislature enacted Senate Bill 7066 (SB7066), which defined "all terms of sentence" to explicitly include payment of LFOs, even if converted to civil liens. The plaintiffs brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses, the Twenty-Fourth Amendment's prohibition against poll taxes, the First Amendment (speech and association), and the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA). They sought declaratory and injunctive relief.

Presiding Judge Robert L. Hinkle, who oversaw the consolidated cases, initially granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on October 18, 2019. This injunction allowed the 17 named individual plaintiffs to register and vote if they asserted or showed a genuine inability to pay their LFOs. The State appealed, and the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the preliminary injunction on February 19, 2020, in *Jones v. Governor of Fla., 950 F.3d 795 (11th Cir. 2020)*. The appellate court held that conditioning voting rights on the payment of LFOs violated the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause as applied to felons genuinely unable to pay, applying heightened scrutiny. Separately, on January 16, 2020, the Florida Supreme Court issued an advisory opinion, *Advisory Op. to the Governor Re: Implementation of Amendment 4, 288 So. 3d 1070 (Fla. 2020)*, agreeing that "all terms of sentence" in Amendment 4 included LFOs.

Following the preliminary injunction, Judge Hinkle certified a class representing all persons eligible to vote but for unpaid LFOs (for the Twenty-Fourth Amendment claim) and a subclass of those genuinely unable to pay (for the Fourteenth Amendment claim) on April 7, 2020. A bench trial was held from April 27 to May 6, 2020. The district court's findings of fact from trial included that the "overwhelming majority" of felons with unpaid LFOs were genuinely unable to pay; that state records for LFOs were decentralized, inconsistent, and often impossible for felons to ascertain; that the State's Division of Elections had not screened a single felon registrant for LFOs and projected completion by 2026 or later without additional resources; and that the risk of criminal prosecution for false affirmation deterred eligible voters. The court also found that the State's newly adopted "every-dollar method" for calculating LFO payments was irrational and undermined its "debt-to-society" rationale. The court determined that many fees and costs were, in substance, taxes used for government funding.

On May 24, 2020, Judge Hinkle issued a permanent injunction, *Jones v. DeSantis, ___ F. Supp. 3d ___, 2020 WL 2618062 (ND Fla., May 24, 2020)*. The court declared Florida's pay-to-vote system unconstitutional as applied to individuals genuinely unable to pay LFOs, for amounts unknown or undeterminable, and for fees and costs (deemed "taxes"). It allowed the requirement to pay determinable fines and restitution for those able to pay. The injunction also mandated an advisory opinion process and a compliant voter eligibility notice, and enjoined the use of the non-compliant voter registration form. Claims of race discrimination, gender discrimination, excessive fines, and Ex Post Facto violations were dismissed.

The State again appealed the permanent injunction to the Eleventh Circuit, and the McCoy/Singleton plaintiffs cross-appealed. The Eleventh Circuit granted the State's motion to stay the permanent injunction pending appeal, a decision the Supreme Court declined to overturn in *Raysor v. DeSantis, 591 U.S. ____ (2020)*. Ultimately, on September 11, 2020, the Eleventh Circuit, sitting en banc, reversed the district court's judgment and vacated the permanent injunction, *Jones v. Governor of Fla., No. 20-12003 (11th Cir. 2020)*. The appellate court found that SB7066 did not violate the Equal Protection Clause under rational basis review (overruling its prior heightened scrutiny finding), nor did it violate the Twenty-Fourth Amendment, or the Due Process Clause. The case was remanded for further proceedings on the cross-appeal.
results.CW-CA-0005:
The case, *Katie A., et al. v. Diana Bonta, et al.*, was initially filed on July 18, 2002, as a statewide class action on behalf of children in California's foster care system or at imminent risk of placement, who had documented mental illnesses or conditions and needed individualized mental health services. The plaintiffs were represented by various private and non-profit legal organizations, including the American Civil Liberties Union, Western Center on Law and Poverty, Protection & Advocacy, Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law, and National Center for Youth Law. The lawsuit alleged systemic failures by state agencies (California Department of Health Services/Care Services and Department of Social Services, and their directors) and Los Angeles County agencies (Department of Children and Family Services and its directors) to provide legally mandated mental health services. These failures allegedly violated the Medicaid Act's Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions (42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq.), the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, Article I, Section 7(a) of the California Constitution, and California Government Code § 11135 et seq. Claims were brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to compel the provision of necessary community-based mental health services.

The case was initially presided over by Judge A. Howard Matz, and later reassigned to Judge John A. Kronstadt. An earlier related case, *CV 98-4181 AHM*, was consolidated with this action. Another related case, *Emily Q. v. Bonta*, was also referenced in proceedings.

After an First Amended Complaint was filed on December 20, 2002, the court granted class certification on June 18, 2003, for a statewide class, though one named plaintiff, Gary E., was excluded as a class representative. On July 16, 2003, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiffs and the Los Angeles County defendants. This settlement, which was court-enforced, required the county to ensure prompt, individualized mental health services in home-like settings, prevent removal, afford placement stability, and provide care consistent with professional standards.

On March 14, 2006, the district court granted a preliminary injunction (reported at 433 F.Supp.2d 1065) against the State defendants, mandating the provision of wraparound services and therapeutic foster care (TFC) statewide. However, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed and remanded this order on March 23, 2007 (reported at 481 F.3d 1150), finding the district court applied an erroneous legal interpretation of the Medicaid Act's EPSDT provisions. Following remand, a renewed motion for preliminary injunction was filed but was subsequently vacated as moot without prejudice to re-filing.

Disputes over the Los Angeles County settlement's enforcement arose, with plaintiffs filing a motion to compel compliance. These disputes concerned the county's progress in screening, providing services to children not removed from homes, addressing placements with Foster Family Agencies, reducing reliance on congregate care, ensuring intensive services in D-rate homes, training staff, securing funding, and developing adequate data and quality review systems.

Ultimately, a comprehensive settlement agreement between the plaintiffs and the State defendants was finalized and approved by the court on December 5, 2011, through a stipulated judgment. This court-enforced settlement aimed to facilitate coordinated, comprehensive, community-based mental health services (Intensive Care Coordination - ICC, Intensive Home Based Services - IHBS, and Therapeutic Foster Care - TFC) by supporting a new service structure and fiscal system, ensuring effective quality-based oversight and training, and specifically addressing the intensive needs of a subclass of foster children. Key deliverables included developing a Medi-Cal Documentation Manual, amending the State Plan for Medicaid, establishing a shared management structure between state agencies, developing cross-system training, improving data collection, and undertaking a statewide readiness assessment of counties. The court retained jurisdiction over this State settlement for 36 months following approval, expiring on December 5, 2014.

Richard Saletta was appointed as a Special Master, and an Advisory Panel also contributed to monitoring. Both the Special Master and Advisory Panel regularly filed reports documenting progress and challenges in implementing both settlement agreements. These reports highlighted successes such as increased DCFS staffing and capacity for Child and Family Team (CFT) facilitation, but also noted continuing challenges including high DCFS caseloads, low CFT meeting frequency, the cessation of an initially promising "immersion process" for implementing reforms, underutilization of specialized mental health services like Wraparound and Intensive Field Capable Clinical Services (IFCCS), persistent numbers of children in congregate care, generally low practice quality scores (QSRs), and limitations in the Department of Mental Health's data systems.
results.CJ-MD-0001:
On January 19, 2006, Vernon Evans, Jr., a death-sentenced inmate, filed a civil action in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland against the Secretary of the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS), the Commissioner of the Maryland Division of Correction (DOC), the Wardens of the Maryland Correctional Adjustment Center and Metropolitan Transition Center, and unidentified execution personnel. Evans, represented by private counsel, brought the action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging that the state's lethal injection practices and procedures created a grave and unnecessary risk of cruel and unusual punishment, violating his Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights to the U.S. Constitution. He sought a permanent injunction against the use of these procedures and a declaratory judgment of their unconstitutionality.

Evans specifically challenged the DOC's three-drug cocktail—sodium pentothal, pancuronium bromide, and potassium chloride—arguing that it unnecessarily risked conscious suffering. He contended that the protocol's use of an ultra-short acting barbiturate (sodium pentothal) in "bursts" rather than continuous administration, combined with the absence of adequately trained medical personnel to administer and monitor anesthesia, created a high risk that inmates would be conscious during the administration of the painful paralytic agent (pancuronium bromide) and heart-stopping drug (potassium chloride). Evans, with a history of intravenous drug use, also highlighted the risk of failed peripheral intravenous access, potentially necessitating painful "cut-down" or central line procedures by unqualified staff. He argued the state's methods fell below generally accepted standards for animal euthanasia by the American Veterinary Medical Association.

On February 1, 2006, Chief Judge Benson Everett Legg of the U.S. District Court denied Evans's motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, finding that Evans had not shown a substantial and unnecessary risk intrinsic to the procedure or that it was likely to fail as applied to him. Evans appealed this decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which denied an injunction pending appeal on February 3, 2006. Evans subsequently dismissed his federal appeal on February 15, 2006.

Contemporaneously, on January 20, 2006, Evans, joined by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of Maryland (ACLU), and Maryland Citizens Against State Executions (CASE), filed a separate complaint in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City. This state action sought injunctive and declaratory relief, alleging that the DOC's execution protocols violated the Maryland Death Penalty Procedures Statute (Md. Code Ann., Corr. Servs. §§ 3-905 - 3-909) and Maryland's Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (Md. Code Ann., State Gov't §§ 10-101 - 10-139) because they were not properly adopted regulations. The Circuit Court for Baltimore City denied a temporary injunction. The Maryland Court of Appeals, in a consolidated review (No. 122), later ruled on December 19, 2006, that the organizational plaintiffs lacked standing. However, it found merit in Evans's claim that the DOC's lethal injection checklist constituted a "regulation" under the APA and was ineffective because it had not been adopted in conformance with statutory requirements. The Court of Appeals vacated the Circuit Court's order and remanded the case with instructions to enjoin enforcement of the lethal injection checklist until the state complied with the APA or the Legislature exempted the protocols. This ruling was reported as 396 Md. 256 (2006).

Following the Maryland Court of Appeals' decision, the federal case proceeded. Chief Judge Legg reopened and denied the state's motion to dismiss on September 14, 2006, and held a bench trial from September 18 to November 15, 2006. On February 21, 2007, the parties filed a consent motion to stay the federal proceedings, citing pending legislative bills in the Maryland General Assembly that could either exempt death penalty protocols from APA requirements or repeal the death penalty entirely. The Baltimore County State's Attorney agreed not to seek a warrant of execution until a final order in the federal litigation. The U.S. District Court granted this motion to stay on February 22, 2007, and required periodic status reports. The case was administratively closed on August 16, 2012, pending the final resolution of these legislative and administrative processes.
results.PN-NY-0014:
The case, *Jaenean Ligon, et al. v. City of New York, et al.*, was initially filed on March 28, 2012, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. The plaintiffs were twelve New York City residents (Black and Latino, some minors) and a class of similarly situated individuals, represented by private counsel including the New York Civil Liberties Union Foundation, The Bronx Defenders, LatinoJustice PRLDEF, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, and Shearman & Sterling LLP. They sued the City of New York, its Police Commissioner, and several New York City Police Department (NYPD) officers, alleging unconstitutional stop, question, search, citation, and arrest policies implemented under "Operation Clean Halls" (later renamed the Trespass Affidavit Program, or TAP). The plaintiffs asserted violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution (including the Equal Protection Clause), Article I, Sections 8 and 12 of the New York Constitution, the Fair Housing Act, and New York common law claims for false arrest, false imprisonment, assault, battery, and malicious prosecution. They sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief to halt and reform these practices, and monetary damages.

The case was assigned to Judge Shira A. Scheindlin and was related to *Floyd v. City of New York* (08 Civ. 1034) and *Davis v. City of New York* (10 Civ. 699), which also challenged NYPD stop-and-frisk practices. On September 24, 2012, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, which Judge Scheindlin granted in part on January 8, 2013 (amended February 14, 2013). The ruling found a clear likelihood that the plaintiffs could prove the NYPD engaged in a widespread practice of unconstitutional trespass stops outside TAP buildings in the Bronx. On February 11, 2013, the court certified a preliminary injunction class for individuals stopped or at risk of being stopped in or around Bronx TAP buildings without legal justification.

On August 12, 2013, Judge Scheindlin issued a joint Remedial Order for *Ligon* and *Floyd*, mandating reforms to NYPD policies, training, supervision, monitoring, and discipline regarding stop-and-frisk practices, and appointing Peter L. Zimroth as an independent Monitor to oversee the process. The City of New York appealed both the preliminary injunction and the Remedial Order. Additionally, several police unions (the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Detectives' Endowment Association, Lieutenants Benevolent Association, Captains' Endowment Association, and Sergeants Benevolent Association) moved to intervene and join the appeal.

On October 31, 2013, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit stayed Judge Scheindlin's orders and reassigned the cases to Judge Analisa Torres, citing an appearance of partiality by Judge Scheindlin. Following a change in mayoral administration, the City sought a limited remand to pursue settlement, which the Second Circuit granted on February 21, 2014. On July 30, 2014, Judge Torres denied the police unions' motions to intervene, finding them untimely and lacking a direct, substantial, and legally protectable interest. She also modified the Remedial Order, limiting the Monitor's term to no sooner than three years after the implementation of immediate reforms, contingent on the City demonstrating substantial compliance. The Second Circuit affirmed Judge Torres's denial of intervention and granted the City's motion to dismiss its appeals with prejudice on October 31, 2014, allowing the remedial process to proceed under Judge Torres's supervision.

On July 19, 2017, the parties reached a Stipulation of Settlement and Order, which resolved the *Ligon* action. Key terms of the settlement included:
*   **Class Definition:** Expanded to include individuals stopped, frisked, arrested, searched, or summonsed inside or outdoors near TAP buildings without legal justification.
*   **Principles:** Acknowledged legal rights of residents/visitors, importance of effective and respectful policing, and necessity of constitutional compliance in trespass enforcement.
*   **NYPD Enforcement Standards:** Required NYPD officers to adhere to specific "objective credible reason" (Level 1), "founded suspicion" (Level 2), and "reasonable suspicion" (Level 3) standards for encounters and stops in or around TAP buildings, explicitly stating what circumstances (e.g., mere presence, refusal to identify, broken locks) are insufficient for suspicion. Mandated completion of standardized Stop Reports and Trespass Crimes Fact Sheets (TCFS) for relevant incidents, and specified limits on frisks and searches.
*   **Policy Revisions:** Required revisions to NYPD Patrol Guide 212-59 (Interior Patrol of TAP Buildings) and Administrative Guide 303-27 (Trespass Affidavit Program) to incorporate these standards, including new criteria for TAP building enrollment and renewal based on documented criminal activity or complaints.
*   **Training:** Mandated training for all relevant NYPD members on the new enforcement standards and TAP administration policies.
*   **Monitoring:** The existing Court-Ordered Monitoring by Peter L. Zimroth was incorporated, to continue for the duration of the *Floyd* action's monitoring, overseeing reforms related to training, supervision, auditing, monitoring, and discipline concerning TAP enforcement. Monitoring for TAP Administration procedures would conclude one year after the settlement's effective date if in substantial compliance.
*   **Damages & Fees:** The City agreed to pay $235,000 to the Named Plaintiffs for individual claims and $2,585,101 in attorneys' fees and $55,432 in costs/expenses through June 30, 2016, with provisions for future fees.
*   **Court Jurisdiction:** The court retained jurisdiction to review, enforce, and ensure compliance.

Since the settlement, Peter L. Zimroth has continued to serve as Monitor. His reports (including the First, Second, Eighth, and Tenth Reports) document significant progress in implementing reforms. The NYPD has revised its policies on stop-and-frisk (PG 212-11), racial profiling (PG 203-25), and interior patrols for NYCHA and TAP buildings (PG 212-60, PG 212-59). A new electronic Stop Report form with narrative sections, and a TCFS for trespass arrests, have been implemented. Training programs for recruits, in-service officers, and supervisors have been updated to reflect new policies, including implicit bias and procedural justice training. The NYPD has also expanded the use of body-worn cameras (BWCs) citywide and developed "RISKS Reviews" to monitor compliance. An MOU was signed with the Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB) on November 21, 2019, to expedite BWC footage production for investigations. The NYPD also implemented a program to collect and act on adverse findings regarding officer conduct. Notable outcomes include a significant reduction in TAP building enrollment (from 3,591 in Q1 2017 to 354 in Q2 2019) and a more than 70% decline in trespass arrests in NYCHA properties from 2014-2018. Monitor reviews of BWC footage show high rates of compliance with constitutional standards for encounters, though concerns persist regarding the underreporting of stops and the thoroughness of supervisory reviews and investigations into profiling allegations.
results.PC-AL-0034:
The U.S. Department of Justice, on behalf of the United States of America, initially filed this civil rights lawsuit on May 28, 2015, against the State of Alabama and the Alabama Department of Corrections (ADOC), which operates the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women. The action was brought under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, alleging that the defendants' actions and omissions constituted a pattern or practice of depriving women prisoners of their rights under the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution, specifically by failing to protect them from harm and serious risk of harm due to sexual abuse and harassment, and by violating their constitutional right to bodily privacy. The U.S. sought a declaratory judgment affirming these constitutional violations and permanent injunctive relief to ensure lawful conditions of confinement.

The factual basis for the case stemmed from a U.S. Department of Justice investigation, which concluded that the State of Alabama failed to protect women prisoners at Tutwiler from pervasive sexual abuse and harassment by correctional staff. Findings included instances of rape, fondling, voyeurism, coerced sexual activity in exchange for necessities or to avoid punishment, and a generally "sexualized environment." The investigation highlighted deliberate indifference by officials, inadequate reporting and investigation processes (including retaliation against those who reported abuse), and systemic deficiencies. These deficiencies involved critically low staffing levels (with a particular lack of female officers), inadequate or non-existent gender-responsive policies, insufficient data collection and analysis, and an architectural design that lacked privacy and created numerous blind spots. Prior to this suit, the U.S. Department of Justice had issued findings in 1995 noting inappropriate sexual contact, and reports from the Bureau of Justice Statistics (2007) and the Equal Justice Initiative (2012) had also detailed ongoing sexual violence at Tutwiler.

The case was presided over by Judge Myron H. Thompson. Rather than proceeding to trial, it was resolved through a Joint Motion to Enter Settlement Agreement. On June 18, 2015, the court granted this motion, adopting the settlement agreement as a consent decree and conditionally dismissing the case without prejudice, while explicitly retaining jurisdiction to enforce the decree. The court’s opinion in the matter is reported at 2:15cv368-MHT (WO).

The consent decree mandated extensive reforms to address the identified issues. Key terms included: full compliance with the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA) standards; establishing multiple internal and external confidential reporting mechanisms for prisoners and staff, protected from retaliation; ensuring prompt, thorough, and objective investigations into all allegations; implementing appropriate disciplinary actions for staff, with termination being the presumptive sanction for sexual abuse; developing gender-responsive policies, training for all staff (including on LGBTQI inmate management, use of force, and inmate discipline), and a gender-responsive classification system for women prisoners (including risk assessment for victimization/abusiveness); maintaining adequate staffing levels, particularly for female officers; addressing architectural features that compromised prisoner privacy; and establishing robust quality improvement and data collection systems, including a Risk Management System (RMS) and routine inmate polling. The decree is set to terminate upon the defendants achieving and maintaining "substantial compliance" with all substantive provisions for three consecutive compliance reports, equating to 18 consecutive months.

A court-appointed monitor, initially Jennie Lancaster and subsequently Kathleen Dennehy (appointed August 26, 2016), oversees compliance. As of the Monitor’s Eighth Compliance Report, filed on August 27, 2019, 41 sections of the agreement were deemed in "substantial compliance," while 2 sections remained in "partial compliance." Persistent challenges noted in the report include chronic understaffing of correctional officers (only 44% of positions filled as of June 30, 2019), ongoing issues with officer recruitment and retention (especially for women), and difficulties in validating the Alabama Peace Officers' Standards and Training Commission’s (APOSTC) Physical Agility/Ability Test (PAAT) for a corrections environment, particularly concerning gender-norming, which continues to impact female candidates. The report also highlighted recurring concerns regarding a small number of staff allegedly using unprofessional, abusive, or racially insensitive language with inmates, and a pattern of inmates making false PREA reports to manipulate housing assignments or target staff.
results.ED-MI-0001:
On November 8, 2006, a coalition of civil rights organizations, labor unions, and numerous individual Black, Latino/a, Native American, and white students and prospective university applicants, represented by private counsel Scheff & Washington, P.C., filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. The plaintiffs challenged Proposal 2, a newly adopted amendment to the Michigan Constitution (Article I, Section 26), which prohibits state entities, including public colleges and universities, from granting preferential treatment based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public employment, education, or contracting. The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause and First Amendment rights, and argued that Proposal 2 was preempted by Titles VI and VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title IX of the Educational Amendments of 1972, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent its implementation.

The initial defendants included the Governor of Michigan and the governing boards of the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, and Wayne State University, and other public educational institutions. The university governing boards, represented by private counsel Butzel Long, P.C., filed a cross-claim against the Governor, seeking a declaratory judgment and a preliminary injunction to delay Proposal 2's implementation for university admissions and financial aid until the end of the current academic cycle, citing academic freedom under the First Amendment and reliance on the Supreme Court's decision in *Grutter v. Bollinger*. The Michigan Attorney General, Michael Cox, represented by the Michigan Department of Attorney General, intervened as a defendant to defend the constitutionality of Proposal 2. Another group of individual students and faculty members at the University of Michigan, the Cantrell plaintiffs, represented primarily by the ACLU Foundation of Southern California, NAACP Legal Defense & Educational Fund, and private firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP, filed a separate class action lawsuit, also challenging Proposal 2 under the Equal Protection Clause, focusing on its impact on the political process. These cases were consolidated before Judge David M. Lawson on January 5, 2007.

The District Court initially granted a stipulated temporary injunction, delaying Proposal 2's implementation for universities until July 1, 2007, but this was stayed by the Sixth Circuit on appeal by an intervening defendant, Eric Russell, a white law school applicant represented by private firms Center for Individual Rights and Cooper & Kirk, PLLC. Russell had successfully argued that his individual interest in immediate enforcement of the ban was not adequately represented by the other parties.

After extensive discovery, which included evidence on the disparate impact of standardized tests and racial segregation in schools, both the Attorney General and Eric Russell moved for summary judgment, arguing Proposal 2 was constitutional. The Cantrell plaintiffs also moved for summary judgment, contending Proposal 2 was unconstitutional. On March 18, 2008, Judge Lawson granted summary judgment to the Attorney General, upholding Proposal 2. The court rejected the plaintiffs' arguments, finding no conventional Equal Protection Clause violation, no preemption by federal statutes, and dismissing the First Amendment claim for lack of standing. The court also dismissed some plaintiffs for lack of standing and denied class certification motions as moot. The Cantrell plaintiffs' subsequent motion to alter or amend the judgment was denied on December 11, 2008.

The plaintiffs appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. A three-judge panel initially reversed the District Court, finding Proposal 2 unconstitutional under the Equal Protection Clause's political-process doctrine, but this decision was vacated when the Sixth Circuit granted en banc rehearing on September 9, 2011. On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit again reversed the District Court, holding by an 8-7 vote that Proposal 2 unconstitutionally altered Michigan's political structure by placing special burdens on racial minorities, citing *Washington v. Seattle School Dist. No. 1* and *Hunter v. Erickson*. The court affirmed the dismissal of Eric Russell as an intervenor, finding his interests were now adequately represented by the Attorney General, and affirmed the denial of the university defendants' motion to be dismissed from the case.

The Michigan Attorney General (now Bill Schuette) sought review from the U.S. Supreme Court, which granted certiorari. On April 22, 2014, the Supreme Court reversed the Sixth Circuit's judgment. The plurality opinion, authored by Justice Kennedy, concluded that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in the Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, particularly in school admissions. The Court distinguished *Seattle* and *Hunter*, noting that those cases involved specific injuries or risks of injury on account of race, which were not present in this case. The Supreme Court's decision thus upheld the constitutionality of Proposal 2.
results.CW-DC-0001:
This class action was initially filed on June 20, 1989, by children in foster care under the supervision of the District of Columbia's Department of Human Services (DHS) and children who had been abused or neglected (or were at risk) and known to the Department. The plaintiffs were represented by attorneys from the Children's Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), a privately funded national organization. The lawsuit named the then-Mayor of the District of Columbia and various officials of the DHS (including the Director, Commissioner of the Commission on Social Services, Acting Administrator of the Family Services Administration, and Acting Chief of the Child and Family Services Division) as defendants in their official capacities.

The core of the complaint alleged that the District's child welfare system systematically denied children their rights under federal law, the U.S. Constitution (specifically the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause), and District of Columbia law. The causes of action were brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, citing violations of federal statutes including the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 and the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, as well as District of Columbia statutes such as the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977 and the Youth Residential Facilities Licensure Act of 1986. The plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment, injunctive relief to remedy these violations, and attorneys' fees and costs.

The factual basis for the case detailed a system in crisis: excessive social worker caseloads, uninvestigated abuse reports, children languishing in "emergency care" for years, untrained staff and foster parents, overcrowded and unsupervised foster homes, nonexistent planning for children's futures, inappropriate use of medication, and a severe lack of specialized placements, often resulting in children being sent to distant states. As a consequence, children remained in foster care for an average of nearly five years, more than triple the national average, suffering irreparable harm.

Following a non-jury trial held from February 6 to 26, 1991, Judge Thomas F. Hogan issued a Memorandum Opinion on April 18, 1991 (762 F.Supp. 959), finding the D.C. officials liable for violating the federal and local statutory rights of all class members, and the Fifth Amendment constitutional rights of those children in the District's foster care. The Court deemed the evidence "outrageous" and the District's dereliction of responsibility "a travesty."

After this finding of liability, the parties negotiated a comprehensive Remedial Order, which the Court entered on August 27, 1991, to reform the child welfare system. The District appealed this judgment. On April 16, 1993, the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals (LaShawn A. v. Kelly, 990 F.2d 1319) affirmed the judgment primarily on the basis of local District of Columbia law, thereby avoiding complex federal statutory and constitutional issues, and remanded the case for the District Court to fashion an order based entirely on local law, if possible. The Supreme Court denied certiorari on this decision.

In response, the District Court re-entered a Modified Final Order (MFO) on January 27, 1994, which was substantially identical to the original Remedial Order but explicitly relied on D.C. law. The MFO established detailed requirements for protective services, child and family care, emergency placements, planning, adoption, staffing, training, and systemic accountability. The District again appealed, but the D.C. Circuit affirmed the MFO in October 1996 (LaShawn A. v. Barry, 107 F.3d 923), finding that it did not exceed the mandates of local law. The Supreme Court again denied certiorari in June 1997 (Barry v. LaShawn A., 117 S.Ct. 2431).

Due to persistent noncompliance, the District Court, on May 22, 1995 (887 F.Supp. 297), found the D.C. officials in civil contempt and imposed a full general receivership over the child welfare system. This receivership was designed to directly manage and reform the system. The District appealed this decision, and in June 1998, the D.C. Circuit (LaShawn A. v. Barry, 144 F.3d 847) remanded the receivership order, finding that its authorization for the receiver to disregard local law was too broad.

The receivership was eventually terminated by consent order in October 2000, subject to a probationary period. Following this, the Court approved an Implementation Plan (IP) in 2003, and subsequently an Amended Implementation Plan (AIP) on February 27, 2007, setting forth new benchmarks and strategies for compliance. Disputes over enforcement continued, and on October 7, 2008, the Court issued a Stipulated Order to address ongoing contempt allegations and require a comprehensive annual strategy plan.

In April 2010, the District Court again found D.C. officials, including Mayor Adrian M. Fenty, in civil contempt for failing to comply with the Stipulated Order (Order, April 5, 2010). The Court simultaneously denied the District's motion to terminate the consent decree and partially denied its motion to modify the Court Monitor's authority. The District appealed these rulings, but the appeals were voluntarily dismissed in 2011.

On December 17, 2010, the Court approved a new Implementation and Exit Plan (IEP), replacing prior plans and setting specific outcomes and exit standards for the District to achieve by the end of 2011. The IEP also outlined a path for eventual termination of judicial oversight. Through subsequent years, the Court Monitor continued to report on the District's progress, noting both achievements and persistent challenges, particularly in timely investigation closures, quality of services, and permanency outcomes.

On August 29, 2019, the parties jointly requested and the Court approved an Exit and Sustainability Plan (ESP), replacing the IEP. This plan designated 56 "Outcomes to be Maintained" (standards already achieved and no longer requiring external monitoring) and identified 23 "Outcomes to be Achieved" that still required improvement. The ESP also included commitments for self-regulation, public reporting, and expanding the placement array, providing a framework for the District to demonstrate substantial compliance and ultimately exit court supervision.

Throughout the litigation, the Court consistently awarded attorneys' fees and costs to the plaintiffs, with significant awards made in February 1998 (1998 WL 35243112), April 2000 (2000 WL 4218003), and through various consent orders for monitoring compliance, with the last recorded consent order for fees and costs covering March 1, 2019, through August 31, 2019. The case remains under the oversight of Judge Thomas F. Hogan, with ongoing monitoring and efforts toward full compliance and termination.
